[11] Different forms of health care now 
coexist, forming a pluralistic model. On the one hand, practitioners of traditional medicine (herbalists, healers and midwives, among others) have adopted and adapted the use of certain drugs to take care of illness, while -as Table 2. Form of attention and treatment received by

medicine has incorporated some traditional healing re-sources, such as herbal remedies, into its practice.

 The data analysed in this investigation show a clear 
prevalence of self-care in Mexico associated with demogra-phic and socioeconomic factors as well as with the Table 3 perceived seriousness of the illness. In 1994, certain authors pointed to the 1ack of drugs and other material resources for medical health care in public health institutions, parti-cu1arly those attending the poor and people without Social Security benefits.
[12] This is an additional factor to take into 
account in order to understand why people did not look for medical care, particularly in rural and poor areas.  Another element that must be considered in the case 
of Mexico is the payment of complementary services in clinics and hospitals. Although most primary health care services in public institutions are “free of charge” (that is, without a direct payment for the medica1 service rende-red) the users have to pay certain fees that health care officers consider symbolic and that are meant to “regu1ate the demand”. For those in extreme poverty, however, the-se fees, without representing a significant income for the institutions, have become an additional economic obsta-cle to receiving medical care.
[13] It has been shown that 
groups of low-income ill people seldom use medical care in spite of the seriousness of the disease.
[14] 
 Additionally, the socioeconomic conditions of most 
of the population worsened towards the end of 1994 as the economic crisis deepened. It is estimated that between 1994 and 1996, another 14.7 million Mexicans joined the ranks of extreme poverty, thus reaching a total of 50.9 mi-llions, 55% of the total population.
[15] 
 This analysis shows that self-care prevailed among 
the population living in poor regions and rural areas. It also found that half of those who perceived their health problem as serious opted for self-care and did not look for medical care since they considered medical services to be far too expensive or they could not afford them. For this social group, self-care does not represent a freely chosen personal option, nor is it only a cultural issue. Rather it is an indicator of social inequity in health, revea1ing the unequal access to medical care in Mexico.  Although most of those who opted for self-care eva-
luated their health problem as slight, the way illness is evaluated must be seen in the specific social context, in which the perception of a disease’s seriousness varies ac-cording to its “normality”. In other words, people evaluate and respond to the same symptoms differently depending on their socio-economic characteristics. Among the extre-me poverty groups, certain diseases (such as cough, pain, diarrhoea and other general symp toms) have become part 
of everyday life and of their “normal” health condition and therefore are not considered a question of importance de-serving medical care.
[16] l 75 l
Many of these illnesses could at least hypothetically 
be treated adequately with remedies or drugs sold over 
the counter (OTC). Although over half the self-care cases used drugs, it was not possible to analyse either the type or amount of medication used since the National Health Survey did not collect these data. 
Community studies, however, have found that the 
population uses a wide variety of drugs without any medi-cal prescription. Many drugs not included as OTC drugs are in fact sold over the counter and, even worse, many of them are unsafe or obsolete.
[17,18] 
 Most medical evaluations regarding self-care mainly 
refer to the potential risks involved in using inadequate, unsafe or high risk drugs to treat illness, using or taking inappropriate dosages, incomplete treatments and delays in diagnosing health problems.
[19] From this point of view, 
self-care represents a risk rather than a benefit. Other evaluations, however, suppose self-care, including self-medication, to be positive. Self-medication is considered an act of independence against the ownership and control of medical knowledge and technology by doctors. This, however, does not take into account the negative effects that self-prescription of drugs might have.
[20] Although 
for some health problems, self-care might be an appro-priate response, the particular conditions in which this process takes place must be analysed in order to unders-tand its many consequences.  In the case of the chronic problems analysed (diabetes 
and hypertension), although medical care prevailed, an im-portant proportion of sick people opted for self-care. Are they thus substituting, complementing or simply reprodu-cing medical prescriptions? Sorne chronic patients have learned to control their disease the same as or even better than the doctor, and therefore do not seek medical care during the evolution of the disease unless they face situa-tions they consider abnormal. Some analyses have shown
[6] 
that an appropriate management of drugs, diet, exercise and other measures helps control disease. This, however, depends on the sick person’s social support network. The chronically sick come to share their life with the disease. It is thus important that they themselves or their relatives identify any complicating symptoms during the evolution of the disease, so they can look for appropriate care. The National Health Survey did not obtain any in-
formation regarding specific disease treatments and only recorded whether the sick person had used remedies and/or medication. One out of every four self-attended sick people had not received remedies or drugs. On the con-trary, nine out of every ten of those who received medical care had been prescribed drugs. Although this is related to the demand for health care, it also expresses a certain form of medical practice based on prescrip tion writing, 
the determinants of which have been studied by various authors.
[21] It is nevertheless important to point to the 
fact that both those opting for self-care and those recei-ving medical care, use remedies and drugs simultaneously, which indicates a certain co-existence of traditional and allopathic medicines in Mexico.  The results show certain relevant aspects that help 
understand the way disease is attended and its relation with social and economic factors. They also generate many questions regarding the characteristics of the process of caring for sick people. How many of the self-attended in-dividual s should have been seen by a doctor? How many of those seen by a doctor required a prescription? Of the-se, was the prescribed medicine appropriate? Is there a difference in the evolution of chronic diseases between those who opt for self-care and those who receive medical attention? How appropriate is the health care for chil-dren?  These and other issues should be analysed in regional 
and local studies in order to better understand the pro-cess of caring for disease in Mexico. Given the country’s current socioeconomic situation, self-care is likely to continue as the principal response to illness, especially for the population living in poverty. The question is how to improve self-care as an adequate way to prevent and to attend illness. Solutions to this problem are not easy; of course, they should in the first place include impro-ved living standards. Information and education channels should be developed on the prevention of certain illnesses and the appropriate selection and use of drugs should be considered, among other social and health-ori ented ac-
tions. Efforts should also be made to provide easier access to quality medical care for when the sick and poor person considers this option appropriate. How people respond to illness in Mexico:

Introduction
As countries modernize and develop, motorization increa-
ses, often with an impact on road safety (Castillo and Re-yes, 1997; Roberts, 2001). In Mexico, since 1989, injuries caused by traffic accidents rank third among the ten leading causes of death and are the leading cause of death for per-sons between ages 1 and 64 (Secretaría de Salud, 1995).
Traditionally, road traffic injuries, including occupants 
of motor vehicles, cyclists, motorcyclists and pedestrians, have been considered as a single problem. That is, vulne-rability, exposure conditions, and risk factors involved in their occurrence were considered to be the same (Mohan, 2000). An example of the need for a distinction in factors is the fact that in Mexico City, 54% of deaths by road traffic injuries are pedestrian injuries (Híjar et al., 2000), mainly to adults in productive ages. The number of non fatal, medically attended pedestrian injuries is estimated to be about 13 for each death; that means that about 9500 injured pedestrians a year require medical attention (Híjar et al., 2001).
The study of road traffic injuries as a single item, 
using aggregated measurements, or making regional com-parisons, is not very useful and excludes any possible iden-tification of the magnitude of the problem for individual traffic users, their spatial and local characteristics, thus Road traffic injuries in
an urban area in Mexico.

Methods
Cuernavaca is a city of 600,000 people, located in the cen-tral region of Mexico, 50 km south of Mexico City. It is served by three regional hospitals, two of them belonging to the social security system, and one public hospital; the-re are also some small private hospitals. In this study, we include two general regional hospitals, one public hospital administered by the Ministry of Health, the other by the Mexican Institute of Social Security (Instituto Mexicano del Seguro Social IMSS), and two private hospitals. The population under study included injured people 
who demanded medical attention at the emergency room (ER) of the hospitals included in the study, or people who died from injuries during the period between 15 February and 30 April 2001. A cross-sectional design was used and included only those events which occurred in public pla-ces and where injuries were the cause of demand for ER services or the cause of death. The data were collected through interviews of inju-
red people, based on a structured questionnaire which was applied by previously trained interviewers who were per-manently at the ER of the selected public hospitals, just for the study purposes, 24 h a day during the study period. Death cases were recorded at the forensic service. Analy-ses of death cases are not included in this paper. The studied variables were: age, sex, day and hour of 
occurrence of the event, alcohol consumption during the 6 h prior to the event, pre-hospital care delivered, exter-nal cause divided into: road traffic injuries, intentional injuries, other unintentional injuries. External cause was coded according to ICD, WHO IX Rev (1995) (WHO, 1995) E800±E999. We did a specific analysis of the road traffic category to analyze the differences between demands for emergency care for injuries resulting from crashes and those resulting from pedestrian injuries. The severity of injuries was grouped in two categories: non se-vere, meaning all kinds of injuries that were handled and solved at the ER, and severe, which included patients who needed hospitalization or died as a consequence of inju-ries. The types of injuries and regions where these were located were coded according to ICD, WHO IX Rev (1995) 800±999. The statistical analysis included: description, distri-
bution and categorization of variables. The association between the variables was determined by an estimate of the difference in the proportions, and χ2. The analysis of 
variables associated with the demand of the different ex-ternal causes of injuries was done through the calculation of the odds ratio (OR), with a confidence interval of 95% (CI 95%). The statistical analysis was performed using the Stata 6.0 package. For the cost analysis, we considered as independent 
variables: (A) insurance situation, defined as the right to use social security services (either private or public), as reported by the population (insured/non-insured); (B) external cause, grouped as: road traffic injuries, intentio-nal injuries or another type of unintentional injuries; and (C) type of service-providing institution, grouped in three types of organizations: Mexican Social Security Institute (Instituto Mexicano del Seguro SocialÐI MSS), Ministry of Health (SSA) and private services (for-profit institu-tions). As a dependent variable, we considered the costs of the process of searching for and finding health care. We constructed this variable considering costs of transporta-tion to the care providing unit and costs of health care, including medicines and laboratory tests.
Results
Between 15 February and 30 April 2001, there were 433 people who were injured in public places; that means an average of almost six cases per day, who demanded medi-cal care for injuries at the ERs’ of four hospitals in Cuer-navaca, Mexico. Of these cases, 233 (54%) were due to road traffic accidents, 72% were due to crashes, and 28% were pedestrian and cyclist injuries. During the same time period, 54 deaths occurred on site, of which 30% were due to road traffic injuries.

Discussion
Combining epidemiological and cost approaches allows us to incorporate levels of analysis that lead to a better un-derstanding of the impact of road traffic injuries beyond the health problem, including the economic impact.
Results obtained with respect to sex, age, alcohol 
intake, transfer to the hospital, pre-hospital care, seve-rity and region of injuries, coincide with those reported in other studies (Arreola-Risa et al., 1995; Mock et al., 1998; Arreola-Risa and Speare, 1999). Within the road traffic category, results related to level of schooling, em-ployment status and age allow us to state that this event, as a public health phenomenon, incorporates two types of social actors (drivers and pedestrians) who have very little in common but the urban space where the accident ha-ppened. Besides, these actors belong to very different and contrasting social and probably cultural groups, where one of them is at a disadvantage.
The findings of this study also allow us to identify 
pedestrian injuries as a problem that particularly affects low-income populations and increases inequalities (Arreo-la-Risa et al., 2000) in a population that is already unequal. We must highlight the fact that, although the majority of the uninsured population makes payments that have a lower cost than the cost for the insured population, the uninsured represent 80% of users who have to pay for the service. Thus, in terms of the economic impact to users’ pockets and the health system’s financial protection, the social response to the uninsured is the problem which most urgently needs to be solved. A cost of 3±6 daily minimum salaries for health care is an economic barrier to access for users lacking social security and whose income is no more than a minimum salary (minimum salary per day in Mexi-co is US$ 4.00). In the same way, costs of transportation turned out to be greater for the uninsured population, es-pecially in pedestrian cases, which shows that, in terms of the economic dimension of accessibility, the infrastructure of health services is less accessible. These results stand out because of the fact that the 
uninsured population is mostly outside the formal eco-nomy and thus, has a lower annual income and a more irregular one, while having less protection from health programs. This situation becomes more severe in the case of traffic-related injuries since, compared to intentional accidents and other types of accidents, it is precisely the traffic-related injury which turned out to have a greater cost for health care. This was to be expected; what is rele-vant in this result is that, for the first time, health services required for accidents in Mexico are evaluated from an economic perspective. This aspect is interesting because it goes against the 
principles of the Mexican health system which state that, in terms of equity and economic accessibility, the low-in-come population should pay less for health care. In other words, catastrophic expenses generated by the demand for health services needed after an accident, in this type of population, should be mostly absorbed by the financial protection mechanisms of the health system.  Actually, it is clear that the perspective of costs to the 
consumer of health services is a variable that should be in-cluded in the economic (Hasselberg et al., 2001; Leigh et al., 2000; Arredondo et al., 1999) epidemiological or any other kind of analysis, in order to acquire more knowledge and reach possible solutions to the substantial problems faced by health care systems. This is mainly the case when facing the challenge of how to make health services more accessible and equitable within the framework of present health sector reforms and, particularly, of the 2001±2006 National Health Program, where the Action Program for accidents is one of the main strategies to be implemented (SSA, 2001).Table 5. pacidad permanente, incapacidad temporal, desequilibrio emocional, ausentismo laboral (2, 11, 17) y además, en los daños psicológicos y el impacto social que ocasionan (14, 22). En el caso concreto de la violencia en el hogar, las mujeres constituyen uno de los grupos más afectados. La relación tan cercana entre agredidos y agresores (5, 6), se recrudece en el caso de las mujeres maltratadas por la pa-reja masculina. Diversos estudios (2) señalan que las mujeres mal-
tratadas por sus parejas tienen un mayor riesgo de ser victimizadas nuevamente en comparación de quienes son agredidas por desconocidos; ésta situación aunada a otros factores pone en evidencia el peso de las condiciones so-ciales en la violencia de pareja y su influencia en la uti-lización o no de los servicios de salud, para resolver las lesiones provocadas por ésta (20). Con base a lo anterior, en el año 1999 se aprobó la 
Norma Oficial Mexicana denominada “Criterios para la Atención Médica de la Violencia Familiar NOM- 190-SSA1±1999” (3). Los estudios realizados en México hasta la fecha, no 
han dado cuenta de cuáles son las características de las mujeres que utilizan los servicios de salud para atender las lesiones recibidas a consecuencia de la violencia de pareja, ¿Cuándo utilizan servicios de salud

Material y métodos

una escala de 27 reactivos (23). Esta escala explora los dis-tintos tipos de violencia: psicológica o emocional, sexual y física. Se utilizó el Análisis Factorial para determinar el origen y agrupamiento de los reactivos, y se obtuvie-Salud Mental, Vol. 29, No. 6, noviembre-diciembre 2006 57

La confiabilidad se determinó empleando el Alpha de Cronbach, que documentó una consistencia de 0.99. Con la combinación lineal de estos factores se construyó el In-dice de Severidad de Violencia de Pareja (ISVP) que se categorizó en: 1) No violencia; 2) media ± DS violencia no severa; 3) media más valores por arriba de 1 DS como violencia severa (24).
Selección de las mujeres entrevistadas
Se realizó un muestreo probabilístico estratificado bietá-pico. En la primera etapa, se seleccionaron unidades mé-dicas con probabilidad proporcional acorde al tamaño por tipo de institución. En la segunda, se utilizó un muestreo sistemático para la selección de mujeres mayores de 14 años usuarias de servicios de salud. Las consideraciones éticas se resolvieron informando a las mujeres selecciona-das sobre los objetivos del estudio y a quienes aceptaron participar, se les solicitó otorgar su consentimiento por escrito, y se les garantizó la confidencialidad de la infor-mación. La tasa de respuesta fue de 98%.
Las variables analizadas fueron las siguientes: 
1) Relacionadas con la usuaria: edad y sexo; escolaridad, actividad laboral e ingreso económico en los 15 días previos a la entrevista, acceso a los servicios de salud de la seguridad social, condición civil y capacidad para decidir sobre el gasto en el hogar. Asimismo se inclu-yó el consumo de alcohol tanto de la mujer como de su pareja.
2) Búsqueda de apoyo en el personal de salud.3) Tipo de institución que proporcionó la atención (Se-guridad social o abierta).*
Se generó un índice de estrato socioeconómico (16) em-pleando una combinación lineal de cuatro variables: pro-medio de escolaridad relativa de los integrantes del hogar, el trabajo de más alto nivel (en términos de ingreso) en el hogar, el número de electrodomésticos, y la ausencia de hacinamiento.
³ El índice se categorizó como bajo, medio 
y alto. La Variable dependiente se definió como la utilización 
de servicios de salud para atender alguna de las lesiones provocadas por violencia de pareja. Un ejemplo de cómo se exploró es el siguiente: ¿A consecuencia del maltrato que sufrió en los últimos doce meses, usted presentó moreto-nes? En el caso de una respuesta afirmativa se preguntaba a la entrevistada si había acudido a alguna institución de salud para atenderse esa lesión. Estas preguntas se hicieron respecto a trece diferentes tipos de lesiones y la forma en que se estructuraron permitió identificar además el tipo de lesión y su gravedad. Esta última se definió a partir del tipo de servicio de salud que se requirió para atender la lesión. Se realizó un análisis bi-variado utilizando chi cuadra-
da y regresión logística y, multivariado, empleando regre-sión logística binaria. El modelo final incluyó las variables que en el análisis bivariado mostraron un valor de p<0.25 (7). Después de fijar los efectos principales, se probaron las interacciones y se sostuvieron en el modelo final solamente si el valor era de p<0.15. El ajuste global del modelo se verificó con la prueba de bondad de ajuste de Pearson, y se le consideró adecuado si el valor era de p>0.10. Los paque-tes estadísticos empleados fueron SPSS 10 (12) y STATA 8.2® (21). Tanto para el bivariado como para el multiva-riado, los intervalos de confianza se calcularon con errores estándar sólidosos. Como los datos observados correspon-dían a mujeres que contaban con la cobertura de parte de una determinada institución, las observaciones dentro del cluster están correlacionadas mientras que las observacio-nes entre los cluster, no lo están (26).
Resultados
Se obtuvo información de 24,958 usuarias de servicios de salud de instituciones públicas que refirieron tener pareja o haberla tenido en el último año. Una de cada cinco in-dicó haber sufrido algún tipo de violencia por parte de su pareja; de éstas, sólo 7.3% acudió a los servicios de salud para atenderse de lesiones intencionales (figura 1). En el cuadro 1 se presentan las principales caracterís-
ticas socioeconómicas de 1,264 mujeres que presentaron alguna lesión debido a la violencia por parte de su pareja; cabe destacar los factores siguientes: edad de entre 25 y 34 años, nivel de estudios de primaria; otras que trabajan fuera del hogar. Más de 80% son casadas o viven en unión libre, poco más de 90% no consumen alcohol o lo hacen de manera ocasional. Un 94% pertenece a los estratos bajo y medio y cerca de la mitad (47%) no tienen acceso a los servicios de la seguridad social; más de dos terceras partes (76%) son víctimas de violencia severa. Aproximadamente la mitad de ellas refiere tener la capacidad para decidir sobre el gasto del hogar.

El 71.7% del total de mujeres de este grupo(n=1264), 
refirió haber sufrido en una sola ocasión alguna lesión leve 
(moretones, dolores en el cuerpo, etc.). Sin embargo, 28.3% señaló presentar la combinación de más de un tipo de le-sión; de este porcentaje 10.8% manifestó haber sufrido le-siones severas que requirieron cirugía y hospitalización.
En el cuadro 2, se observa que las mujeres que pre-
sentaban lesiones físicas visibles o que requerían algún procedimiento médico como sutura de heridas, reducción de fracturas o atención por quemaduras, fueron las que más utilizaron los servicios de salud. Llama la atención, no obstante, que 18% de las mujeres que tuvieron alguna fractura no utilizaron dichos servicios. Los síntomas ge-nerales como desmayos y pérdida de la función de alguna parte del cuerpo fueron los que se asociaron con una mayor demanda de atención. En 16% (n=61) de las mujeres que utilizaron servicios de salud, la lesión fue grave (cuadro 2). Como consecuencia de la violencia sexual, las causas que exigieron mayor atención fueron las infecciones genitales y el sangrado transvaginal.
De las mujeres que acudieron a los servicios de salud 
para atenderse, 45% lo hizo preferentemente en institu-ciones de la seguridad social.
Respecto a la búsqueda de apoyo en el personal de 
salud, solamente 5.9% (n=311) de las mujeres que en el último año han sido maltratadas por su pareja habló con el personal de salud sobre su situación de maltrato. Un punto que hay que destacar es la dificultad de las

Introduction
In this paper we want to explore some of the limitations 
of models of patient involvement in treatment decision-making. Specifically, we will consider the models of inter-pretative decision-making, shared decision- making and informed decision-making. To some extent these limita-tions are simply limitations of models (i.e. models are inhe-
rently and necessarily limitedÐt hat is, so-to-speak, how they work), and we will begin by acknowledging this fact. But we also want to highlight two aspects of the process of decision-making, which, we would argue, are crucial to an understanding of doctor±patient decision-making and yet are substantially neglected by the models. These two aspects relate to the questions ‘which decisions should pa-tients be involved in?’ and ‘how should patients be invol-ved in decision-making?’ More specifically they concern (1) the framing problemÐt he construction of the option-set which both frames decision-making and is, in part, a product of decision-making; (2) the nature of reasoning problemÐ the nature of the reasoning±communication represented in any process of joint decision-making. Lying behind these limitations, we want to suggest, is a more fundamental problem. We would argue that whilst these models represent some very important aspirations, they pay insufficient attention to, and are insufficiently Patient-doctor decision-making
about treatment within the consultation.

much time interrogating the nature and variety of mod-els. We will proceed as if the models discussed have rela-tively clear-cut and broadly similar purposes. However, it is essential to signal at the outset that the role and value of these kinds of model are both contested and varied. However, one thing that might be said by way of gener-alisation is that it is in the nature of models to ‘abstract from’ and simplify the multi-dimensional realities that they represent. (As is often said a map  which contained all 
the information found in the reality it depicted would be valueless as a map .) It is, therefore, not a credible criticism 
of models to point out that they do not include all the things that they might include. Nor can we expect there to be any straightforward ‘match’ between models and the world of practice. There is inevitably an ‘interpreta-tive space’ between the models and practice. Thus, it is not simply that there may sometimes be a kind of mismatch 
between a model and practice, it is also that we are often Social Science & Medicine 62 (2006) 116–124

Having acknowledged some of these complexities 
we will take it that models of patient involvement are 
designed to describe and/or prescribe some conception of ‘good practice’, i.e. patient involvement is being made salient through the models because of its instrumental or 
intrinsic value. Instrumental (or practical) value refers to such things as patient involvement leading to patients who ‘‘make wiser decisions, come to a common under-standing with their physicians, and adhere more fully to treatment’’ (Epstein, Alper, & Quill, 2004); hopefully this leads to a happier, healthier patient. Intrinsic value refers to philosophical or ethical ideals, such as ‘respect for persons’, which underlie or inform patient involvement policies; ideals that can be seen as crucially important in themselves, irrespective of the practical effects of involve-ment. Given that this account describes the basic thrust underpinning models such as the ones considered here, there are three broad sets of evaluative issues that arise about the ‘space’ between models and practice. We could, for example, ask (1) Is there a rough fit between (any of ) these models and some real world practices? (2) What are the factors that might enable or constrain the possible realisation and enactment of the model in practice? (3) Do (or would) enactments of the models serve the instru-mental or intrinsic ends that their advocates would wish? The remarks we make in the review of the models that make up the main body of the paper will touch upon all of these questions, but these questions do not form the central thread of our account. Rather, as we have already indicated, we will concentrate on exploring what we see as some of the limitations of the modelsÐ limitations which, we would argue, make it difficult to answer any of these questions satisfactorily. These models of doctor±patient decision-making, we are suggesting, are not sufficiently well-defined to answer these crucial evaluative questions. It seems to us that before they can be subjected to these kinds of evaluations the underlying assumptions that these models make about the relative roles of professionals and patients need to be questioned and further elaborated.
Describing the decision-making models
Currently, there are four frequently discussed models of patient±doctor decision-making about treatment: Pater-nalistic decision-making, interpretative decisionmaking, shared decision-making and informed decisionmaking (Emanuel & Emanuel, 1992; Laine & Davidoff, 1996; Charles, Gafni, & Whelan, 1997, 1999a, b). There is no universally agreed definition of these models and what they include. On the contrary, there is much confusion and overlap in how these models are understood (Charles et al., 1997). Furthermore, as we will show, there is con-siderable debate about what the application of these mod-els would involve. In broad terms, decision-making models vary in the 
respective roles that doctor and patient take in the final selection of treatment. From the point of the patient this means the models differ according to the degree to which the patient is able to take part in, and shape, the choice of their treatment (see Fig. 1). In the paternalistic model, practiced over centuries, the doctor chooses the treatment after evaluating information about the disease of the pa-tient, the treatment options and the probabilities of out-comes. In the interpretative model (Emanuel & Emanuel, 1992), the doctor decides about a treatment plan, but does so by taking the values and preferences of the patient into consideration. Shared decision-making means that at least two participantsÐ doctor and patientÐa re involved, both parties (doctors and patients) take steps to partici-pate in the process of treatment decision-making, they share information and a treatment decision is made to which both parties agree (Charles et al., 1997). Finally, in the informed decisionmaking model the patient decides on his or her own after the doctor discloses information about benefits, risks and alternative treatment options.

 The informed decision-making model is superficially 
similar to informed consent as in both cases the patient 
has the final decision-making authority. But there are two crucial differences. First, in contrast to informed decision-making, informed consent is a form of legal authorisa-tion for which certain criteria need to be met before the patient’s authorisation is valid, such as the patient’s com-petence, the patient’s understanding of the information disclosed, freedom from coercion or manipulation by the doctor and the patient’s intended authorisation (Faden & Beauchamp, 1986; General Medical Council, 1998). Sec-ond, in informed decisionmaking the doctor presents all available treatment options and then the patient decides which option to choose, whereas informed consent does not require that the patient select one treatment out of a 
range of options. Usually, the doctor asks the patient for permission relating to one health care intervention whilst 
simply informing about others. Some of these decision-making models derive from 
wider conceptions of doctor±patient interaction and include factors unrelated to the immediate process of decision-making. We will briefly describe these wider conceptions in order to distinguish them from the deci-sion-making models per se and thereby to indicate why we 
have excluded them in our discussion. For instance, shared decision-making comes out of patientcentred medicine. Patient-centred medicine describes the ways in which doctors should practice medicine as a whole including, but not confining itself to, decisionmaking (Weston & Brown, 1995). Its origin lies in the theory that incorporat-ing patients’ subjective experience of disease into clinical practice is an essential element of good medicine (Laine & Davidoff, 1996). Out of six defined interactive compo-nents of the patient-centred process only some elements, such as ‘‘finding common ground regarding management’’ and ‘‘exploration of the disease and patient’s illness expe-rience’’, are directly related to decision-making between the doctor and patient (Weston & Brown, 1995). These elements suggest the use of shared decision-making or interpretative decision-making, according to the patient’s preference. Hence, for the purposes of this paper, we have included the models of shared and interpretative decision-making but not the broader concept of patient-centred medicine. Similarly, the model of concordance promotes a whole 
approach to the doctor±patient encounter rather than solely an approach to decision-making about treatment (Royal Pharmaceutical Society of Great Britain & Merck, Sharp & Dohme, 1997). It shares with patient-centred medicine the assumption that the patient’s experiences of illness need to be incorporated into the patient’s care. According to the definition given in the foundation docu-ment, concordance is defined as ‘‘an agreement reached after negotiation between a patient and a healthcare pro-fessional that respects the beliefs and wishes of the patient in determining whether, when and how medicines are to be taken’’ (Royal Pharmaceutical Society & Merck, Sharp & Dohme, 1997). The authors regarded the concept as ‘‘a new approach to the prescribing and taking of medicines’’. This emphasis suggests that the concept focuses on that part of the consultation which deals with the prescrib-ing and taking of medicines. However, the authors also see concordance as ‘‘an integral aspect and not a detach-able component of the whole process of clinical care.’’ (Here we should note that the model of concordance has been developed over time and many interpretations and amendments have been made to the original concept. It has thereby become increasingly difficult to identify the core components of the model. Hence our use of the foundation document). The model of decision-making found in concordance 
is distinct from the shared decision-making model, both in the assertion that the patient’s view should have pre-cedence and because it allows for the patient to delegate the decision-making authority to the doctor (Pollock, Blenkinsopp, & Grime, 2002). (By contrast, in the shared decision-making model delegating the decision- mak-ing authority to another party is seen as actually falling outside shared decision-making). However whilst noting these important differences in emphasis we would suggest thatÐif the significance of concordance is understood purely in relation to its expression in decision-makingÐthe limitations of the three patient±doctor decision-making models that we are exploring in this paper apply equally to concordance.  It is widely acknowledged that these three models are 
idealisations and that practice rarely reflects only a single model used in its idealised form (Charles et al., 1999b). There are arguably three reasons for this ‘gap’ between models and practice. Firstly, there are approaches which fall, so-to-speak, in intermediate positions between these models or, to put it another way, it is possible to combine elements from various models in one decision-making process. Secondly, the question of which model is most relevant to practice might best be thought of not as a uni-versal question but as one which depends on the clinical circumstances, and on the doctor’s and patient’s prefer-ences and knowledge at specific times and places, amongst l 93 l
other things. For example, in an emergency situation the 
paternalistic model has been advocated (Emanuel & Emanuel, 1992). Thirdly, howeverÐa nd most fundamen-tally as we have mentioned already in the introductionÐit  is not always easy to identify what would count as an ap-plication of a model in practice. In particular, the models reflect different sets of assumptions about practiceÐdif-ferent assumptions about what the respective roles of doc-tors and patients are; or different assumptions about what they ought to be, (depending, that is, on whether we stress their descriptive or their prescriptive functions). 
What, then, are these assumptions? The interpreta-
tive model, for example, assumes that first, the doctor needs to make the decision since he/she has the duty to act in the best interest of the patient and second, that the patient is not able to make a decision due to his/her illness and lack of information and knowledge. By contrast, the informed model assumes that only the patient is able and should decide which kind of health care he or she should receive (Emanuel & Emanuel, 1992). Shared decision-making assumes that the patient is not necessarily able to decide on his/ her own and therefore, it is the doctor’s duty to support the patient’s decision-making (Charles et al., 1997, 1999a, b). This can be achieved by drawing out the patient’s preferences and values, discussing each other’s preferences and agreeing on the decision made. Hence the responsibility for the decision is shared.
In essence, the decision-making models differ in 
their understanding of first, the proper scope of patient autonomy and second, the duties and responsibilities of doctors. First, with regard to patient autonomy, some of the models operate with ‘thicker’ conceptions of au-tonomy. For example, shared decision-making suggests that decision-autonomy depends upon an environment of communication and reflection and isÐ as Emanuel and Emanuel (1992) put itÐa  ‘‘process of moral deliberation’’. In contrast, the interpretative model and the informed decision-making model tend to reflect a dichotomous picture of autonomy which is either present or absence. Here the values are known to the actors and there is less emphasis on reflection and revision. Second, in terms of the responsibility of the doctor, shared decision-making emphasises the duty and responsibility of the doctor to elicit values, preferences or beliefs and to discuss how these may apply to the treatment decision; the paternalis-tic and the informed decision-making models exempt the doctor from this task. In these cases, as well as in the case of interpretative decision-making, the actual process of decision-making is with the doctor or the patient, which means that the weighing of options does not need to be verbalised and thus this process need not be an interactive oneÐindeed,  the final decision can be made outside the patient±doctor encounter. Although we will return to this idea towards the end 
of the paper we should underline here that these sets of assumptions are closely linked to fundamental questions of professional ethics i.e. they embody different concep-tions of the obligations of doctors, different ideas about the ideal forms of professional comportment and patient±doctor relationship structures and different ideas about the proper (and relative) scope of doctor and patient powers and responsibilities. Hence, whether we are us-ing models predominantly prescriptively or descriptively, in using them we are, inevitably, drawing on some back-ground picture of professional ethics.
Limitations of the decision-making models
What are the relationships between these models and clinical realities? As we have noted earlier it does not make sense to look for complete or tidy matches between the two. However, in analysing the decisionmaking models we found two substantial limitations which, we suggest, means that the use of these models for understanding doctor±patient decision-making within the consultation needs to be questioned and re-evaluated. These limita-tions also shed light on the reasons why models such as 
shared decision-making are not widely implemented in practice.
The framing problem—i.e. the construction of the option-
set for decision-making is neglected
The decision-making models neglect an important condi-
tion of treatment decision-making: i.e. how is the option-setÐfr om within which the final treatment decision is madeÐco nstructed? That is, how do doctors and patients discover or determine the range of treatment possibilities from which they are making a choice? In practice, this will very often come down to the question of whether patients are ‘offered’ a range of treatment options. All the models focus on the opportunity to engage in the final selection of treatment and overlook the fact that the number of treatment alternatives considered significantly influences the degree of autonomy exercised. These ob-servational studies, analysing audio-tapes from consulta-tions, assessed not only whether the patient was asked for his/her choice (final authorisation), but they also inves-tigated if the patient was explicitly offered one or more treatment alternatives. In oncology consultations Gattel-lari et al. (2002) found that less than one in two (44%) patients was offered one or more treatment alternatives. Braddock et al. (1999), analysing primary care consulta-tion and consultations between patients and surgeons, re-ported that only around one in ten patients (11%) were offered alternatives. Perhaps most significantly, by mea-suring the time spent in the primary care consultation on various elements of shared decision-making Elwyn et al. (2001b) found that doctors spent the least time on explic-itly mentioning the existence of equally reasonable treat-ment alternatives. This shows that not only do the models not represent the question of the range of treatment op-tions offered to the patient, but also that in practice this element of the decision-making process is frequently ne-glected. Why does the question of the option-set receive such 
little attention both in the decision-making models and in practice? The range of treatment options available to, or offered by, the doctor are likely to fall within a profes-sionally agreed rangeÐ i.e. what some authors call ‘medi-cal reasonable alternatives’ (Whitney, 2003). This range is determined by a number of factors (see Fig. 2): policies, the doctors’ concept of duty and responsibility, the knowledge (and assumptions) of the doctor about the patient’s val-ues and preference (Britten, Stevenson, Barry, Barber, & Bradley, 2000), the doctors’ knowledge about the medical treatments available for a specific diagnosis, medical infor-mation about the treatment options, organisational con-straints (time, costs, etc.) and maintaining a relationship. We will briefly discuss some of the factors influencing 
the option-set in order to analyse their impact on the real scope of decision-making on offer to the patient. Policies are probably the most commonly discussed factor here (Sculpher, Gafni, & Watt, 2002). Health care providers can significantly limit the range of treatment alternatives, for instance through excluding treatments from reim-bursement. The limitation of choice at various levels of the health care system could be pictured as a funnel with various levels of filters. Examples would be the licensing of the medicine, its inclusion in the national reimburse-ment mechanism, national prescribing policy, local health authority policy, then hospital or GP practice formulary and policies. On each level of the funnel the choices can be reduced. One reason why patients are only offered one treatment option can be the effect of policies that reduce the range to a single treatment. In these instances neither the doctor nor the patient may have much direct say in the construction of the option-set. Nonetheless, even in these cases doctors who wish to ‘involve’ patients in decisions about their treatment are presented with communication dilemmas. Thus, for example, Sculpher et al. (2002) discuss the 
actual practicality of shared decision-making in a publicly funded health care system where conflicts between the choice of ‘optimal’ care and funded health care might occur. Doctors may similarly experience dilemmas in providing

They argue that making these distinctions would reduce conflict in the doctor±patient relationshipÐ but it could just as well be argued that acknowledging these complications merely multiplies the dilemmas in balanc-ing professional responsibility with information-sharing and patient autonomy.
The other factors that influence the option-set are 
less well-explored. For instance, it is less clear how far a lack of doctors’ knowledge about treatment options causes restriction in the choice of patients’ treatment in practice. If doctors are not aware of certain treatment options they cannot initiate a discussion about them with, or offer them to, patients. Equally, doctors might be aware of op-tions but have limited knowledge, expertise or experience of using the option, making it difficult to offer confident advice to patients. In either of these cases it is of course possible, in principle, for the patient to initiate discussions about a wider optionsetÐ but (a) given the typical social positions of doctors and patients in relation to clinical knowledge and policy influence, it is likely to be the case that patients generally have less role in the construction of the option-set and (b) even where patients are influential in this respect (perhaps by presenting an option found on the internet) there is obviously a limit to how far doctors can helpfully support patient choice in areas where the doctors themselves lack relevant expertise.
The significance of this problem about the construc-
tion of the option-set depends in large part upon one’s beliefs about the doctor’s professional responsibility. The difference of opinion about when shared decision- mak-ing can or should be practiced stems from conflicting ac-counts of doctors’ responsibility in relation to ‘steering’ treatment choice. Ford, Schofield and Hope (2003), inter-viewing a group of doctors, other health care profession-als and lay people, found two conflicting opinions in play. One opinion was that involvement of the patient in the decision was only legitimate in a situation of equipoise (the existence of two or more treatment options includ-ing the ‘no treatment option’, without particular profes-sional preference for one option); another opinion was that it should always be practiced. On this basis Trevena and Barratt (2003) suggested a compound model of ‘in-tegrated decision-making’, which makes explicit that the locus of decision-making shifts depending on the case in hand. Thus at one end of the spectrum only the patient decides. At the other end only the doctor decides (in situ-ations where the community values override the patient’s right of autonomous action). But in cases of equally effec-tive options the patient and doctor decide together. Simi-larly, Whitney (2003) argues that shared decision-making should only be practiced where there is a ‘medical reason-able alternative’. Models of shared decision-making do not define the 
extent to which the option-set needs to be jointly con-structed by patients and doctors. If patient involvement has a value, there is no absolute reason why it should have 
a role only after the construction of the option-set. We are 
happy to acknowledge that calling for an equal role for doctors and patients in the construction of the option-set would be somewhat other- worldlyÐbut  it is nonethe-less important to question models of patient involvement that do not systematically address this issue. What we are left with are some fundamental ambiguities. For example, accounts of shared decision-making suggest that doctors need to take patient views and beliefs into consideration when proposing treatment alternatives (Charles et al., 1999a). Charles et al. (1997) argue that this means in cer-tain cases, a doctor might mention treatment options and then agree to the patient’s preference for them even when these would not be the doctor’s choice of treatment for the patient. In some cases this may well be what is entailed by shared decision-making but it is very difficult to decide how to draw boundaries around this possibility. How far should doctors allow patients to set the treatment agenda? This is an example of the ‘interpretative gap’ we referred to above. But this is not merely an abstract problem about model conceptualisation. It is a critical ethical dilemma in a world where doctors are, and are held, accountable for the treatments their patients take up.

It is typically described with short ‘umbrella’ phrases such as ‘‘mutual discussion’’ or ‘‘negotiation’’, etc. A literature re-view on instruments measuring patient-involvement in shared decision-making found no single instrument which was developed to measure specifically the ‘in-volvement’ of patients (Elwyn et al., 2001a). The authors concluded that not enough attention has been paid to de-fining the assessment of the process of involvement. Re-cently, the OPTION scale has been developed in order to enable assessment of the process of involvement (Elwyn et al., 2003). Elements such as ‘‘the clinician explores the patient’s expectations (or ideas) about how the problem (s) are to be managed’’ and ‘‘the clinician explores the patient’s concerns (fears) about how the problem (s) are to be managed’’ have been included. Although the OP-TION scale gives a more detailed account of what might be viewed as the essential elements of a joint decision, it does not capture the full process of dialogue and deliber-ation±a process which involves a number of balancing acts, 
as we discuss below. When the full process of dialogue and deliberation is 
neglected there is the danger that in practice, choosing a treatment gets reduced to a largely technical task (Cribb & Barber, 1997). One indication that this happens in practice is the widespread expectation on the part of pa-tients that the doctor is the expert at choosing the ‘right’ treatment (Coulter, 1999). Lying behind this expectation is a concept of prescribing, where the task is seen as simi-lar to solving a mathematical problem. The person famil-iar with the rules can calculate the right answer to the problem. This model of treatment choice not only neglects patient-relative factors (values, lifestyles, preferences, etc.) but also pays insufficient regard to the uncertainties which are present in any treatment choice. As discussed earlier, only one of the factors influencing the range of treatment options offered is a ‘technical’ one, what we called ‘medi-cal information about the treatment’, including benefits and risks (see Fig. 2). To the extent that health policy and health encounters reinforce the perception that choice of treatment is essentially a technical task, patients remain unaware of the full range of factors which influence the range of treatment options, the uncertainties inherent in clinical reasoning and the full potential for their involve-ment in decision-making. Even ‘medical information’, which does rely on tech-
nical and expert knowledge, is limited in its application to an individual patient, as medical information is gained from cohorts of patients, and presented in relation to the effects on a population. Probabilities are not necessarily valid on an individual level (Bellaby, 2000). Prescribing largely involves ‘trial and error’. The real effects of a given treatment to a given patient cannot be predicted with complete accuracy; they can only be gained from obser-vation. In hospital, observation is done under medical surveillance. In primary care, patients themselves report about treatment effects. This ‘trial and error’ approach is used because first, there is no certainty about the effect at an individual level, and second, the large majority of side effects are reversible, so that the risk of this approach seems to be acceptable from the doctor’s perspective. But the extent to which patients are aware of this underly-ing approachÐa n approach at the heart of the clinical decision-making processes they are, in varying degrees, ‘involved’ inÐis  far from clear. Without at least a shared understanding of the ‘rules of the game’, here the actual potential for meaningful involvement is limited. However, this only represents one respect in which 
the absence of a clearer picture, within the models re-viewed, of the intended forms of reasoning±communica-tion is unfortunate. Communication is an intrinsic feature of healthcare. That is to say that communicationÐh ere between doctor and patientÐ is part of care, not just an 
instrumental support to care. Talk between doctors and patients can play a therapeutic role and the consultation is, or can be, a meeting place in which the meanings of pa-tient experiences, and their hopes, fears and expectations are jointly unravelled and explored (Benaroyo & Widder-shoven, 2004). It is only within this context that the role of patient involvement and potential for joint decision-mak-ing can be fully appreciated. However, this entails some acknowledgement within any proposed model not only of the potentially crucial relevance of patient’s values and preferences, and of the possible means of eliciting these within dialogue, but also of the many inherent balancing acts in doctor±patient dialogue. Specifically, there are the balances between the calls upon doctors (a) to guide and support therapeutic communication including, where ap-propriate, helping ‘contain’ or respond to anxiety or other emotions, (b) to ‘make space’ for patients to share respon-sibility to some degree (including responsibility for treat-ment decisions or even decision-framing), (c) to inform or educate patients about relevant aspects of technical judgement and uncertainty and (d) to help elicit the rel-evant preferences of patients and to help ensure that these are adequately incorporated into treatment decisions. Concluding discussion
These models, we have argued, fall short because they give insufficient attention both to which decisions are in the lens (the framing problem) and to the question of how 
decisions should be made (the nature of reasoning prob-lem). Because these are two such fundamental consider-ations it seems to us that any useful model will have to address them more directly. However we would also want to argue that the task of addressing these questions entails facing up to fundamental dilemmas about the nature of professional±patient relationships that the models largely skirt around. Patient involvement is, we agree, rightly ad-vocated for both instrumental and intrinsic reasons and as a necessary corrective to purely paternalistic models of decisionmaking. However, patient involvement cannot really be meaningfully considered without asking care-ful and detailed questions about how it is supposed to ‘fit together’ with expert or professional involvement. Profes-sional involvement is the assumed background condition against which talk of patient involvement makes sense. It is important to bring patient involvement into the picture but in so doing we cannot overlook the fact that there is also a broader frame that is essentially made up of policy and professional judgements. (One of us has expressed this idea elsewhere by noting that the idea of ‘person-cen-tredness’ is inherently and necessarily ‘professionally cen-tred’ (Cribb, 2005); i.e. it could only arise and make sense in a context where professionals are being addressed and being asked to modify their orientation to some degree). Hence the two issues we have highlightedÐt he question of which decisions are ‘left to’ patients, and the question of what might be seen as the choreography of some de-gree of ‘joint’ decision-making. How, in a nutshell, are the patient pieces and the non-patient pieces of this puzzle meant to fit together? As we have already signalled, it seems that answering 
this questionÐa nd hence also evaluating the three mod-els we have reviewedÐdep ends upon making discrimina-tions between different conceptions of professional ethics. This is because lying in the background of the models are different accounts of professional obligations, ideals of professional comportment, patient± doctor relationship structures and of the appropriate scope of doctor and pa-tient powers and responsibilities. We suggest, therefore, that these issues of professional ethics need to be addressed explicitly and systematically within the development or use of potential models. The core issue, we would argue, is the construction of an account of decision-making which recognises the ways in which professional decisionmaking is bound up with complex networks of accountability, and yet which also recognises the full importance of patient involvement in decision-making. It is, we suggest, the fact that professionals are accountable to policy communities, institutions, professional bodies and specific and general populations that explains the centrality of their role in both theoretical and empirical accounts of decision-mak-ing, including the relative paucity of evidence for shared decisionmaking in practice. There is no ‘cost free’ way of making unqualified affirmations about both professional accountability and patient involvement. In practice dif-
ferent balances have to be struck and although advocates of various models may want to strike balances with dif-ferent emphases they must, we are arguing, be prepared to explain how they see these two things fitting together. Indeed, we would argue that the fundamental limitation of models of patient involvement is notÐ as is sometimes assumedÐt he potential difference between professional expertise and lay expertise, but rather the deep seated ethical and legal differences between professional and lay patterns of accountability. Our guiding thought here should not be read as antipathetic to more extensive pa-tient involvementÐin principle, revision to shared deci-sion models could go in either direction, depending upon the values of the health policy and/or the case in hand. Revisions could set out more explicitly the limits to pa-tient involvement given the  many other demands on the policy±professional nexus. Or they could, at least in some cases, explicitly increase the accountability of patients for their choices (and diminish that of professionals)Ðe .g. by requiring  patients to forego rights of complaint or of legal action, where they choose options that are not professionally recommended.

Among the possible interpretations of these facts, is that the incidence of diabetes is increasing at such a high rate that, despite the very significant mortality, the prevalence remains increasing. Regardless of the explanation(s) of this serious circumstance, the situation is imposing an enormous strain on the national health care system. Moreover, there is evidence to support that diabetes and its chronic com-plications, generate the most significant costs of the entire health care expenditure.4 There is a strong need for more information in order to implement strategies to contain the epidemic and handle its consequences by investing wisely in strategies that need to be evaluated constantly. Materials and Methods
The design, methods and procedures of the National Health and Nutrition Survey 2006 (ENSANUT 2006) has been described elsewhere.
2 Briefly, with a probabi-
listic multistage stratified cluster sampling design aimed to have a national and state level representative sample, a total of 45 446 adults aged 20 years or more were exam-ined, a questionnaire, blood pressure and anthropometric measurements were included. Blood samples were col-lected from 30% of a randomly selected adults, most of them (91.3%) with more than 8 hours of fasting. Serum samples were frozen at -70 ° C for future analysis. From the frozen serum bank, a sub-sample of 6 613 participants was randomly chosen to determine glucose, insulin, trig-lycerides, total cholesterol, HDL-cholesterol and HbA1c (in diabetic subjects). For these analysis we concentrated on adults who self 
reported a previous diagnosis of diabetes established by a physician and responded affirmatively that they receive medical treatment, either from the entire survey (n=2 644 diabetics) or from the biological sub sample with meta-bolic biomarkers information and with fasting of at least 8 hrs. (n= 428). The protocol was approved by the Ethical Commit-
tee of the Instituto Nacional de Salud Pública. All pa-tients signed informed consent.
Variables definition
The diagnosis of diabetes was accepted when the partici-pant declared he /she was diagnosed by a physician and was under treatment. The duration of disease as well as the specific treatment was registered. Responses were ac-cepted without confirmation.  The diagnosis of hypertension was accepted when 
the participant declared he/she was diagnosed by a phy-sician as hypertensive and declared he or she was taking prescribed antihypertensive medicines, regardless of the blood pressure level. Access to health care was determined by asking the subject if he or she had medical insurance and to specify which kind. No attempt was made to con-firm participant’s response by requesting official docu-mentation of the health care provider. Previous health care access was not ascertained. Health Care System is composed of the following institutions: Instituto Mexi-cano del Seguro Social (IMSS), the Instituto de Seguri-dad y Servicios Sociales para los Trabajadores del Estado (ISSSTE), the recently developed Seguro Popular (SP) hereby Popular Security, the health services administered by the federal government and those administered locally by each state (classified within “Other” category) and the private health care sector (named “Private”) During the interview, participants were asked if they identified themselves as indigenous and if they spoke an aboriginal dialect. The response was accepted without confirmation. The years of study were also taken as they were reported by the participant. Body mass index was calculated us-ing the standard formula. Laboratory measurements were performed using the methods that are described in other papers published in this journal. The biomarkers levels were categorized to evaluate the proportion of diabet-ic subjects in adequate control using the cutoff points defined by the Mexican and international guidelines. Participants answers to questions regarding preventive measures in their care, such as ophthalmologic and feet exam, renal evaluation or aspirin preventive treatment, were recorded, no chart review or confirmatory methods were attempted.
Analysis
Given our focus on medical care all descriptive analysis were stratified according to the institution where the diabetic patient reported to receive their medical care. We describe a set of variables that are related to the quality of care. For those indicators that do not need biomarker measurements (process of care) we used the entire sample of diabetics from the survey (2 644) and for biomarker indicators (interme-diate outcomes) we used only the diabetics from the bio-logical subsample (428).All biomarkers were measured at the Instituto Nacional de Salud Pública. We estimated the proportion or means of each variable taking into account the sampling weights and considered the survey’s complex sampling design to obtain variances. Statistical analysis was performed using a commercial package. Standard statistical procedures were performed using this platform.l 101 l

 Table II shows the variables that can be used to assess 
the characteristics of this patient population. Most of the patients of this population are within the age range of 30-60 years. About 22% of the subjects had less than 2 years of duration of the disease. More than half of the entire diabetic population has more than 4 years of duration of the disease. The peak of onset of disease occurs at the ages between 30-60 years. A substantial proportion of individ-uals are diagnosed at either end of the spectrum, younger and older. Regarding therapy, the majority (85.6%) are treated with oral agents. A significant proportion of pa-tients (6.2%) reported not using therapy. The proportion of individuals using insulin as a single therapeutic agent or in combination with oral agents is small. For Table III we used only the diabetics from the bio-
logical subsample (428), it shows the biomarker indicators (intermediate outcomes) associated to the assessment of control. The proportion of individuals that had total cho-lesterol higher than 200 mg/dl is noticeable in all groups. Even in the group “Other” in spite of the small number of cases, the number of subjects with hypercholesterolemia is high (more than 36%).The proportion of subjects with low levels of HDL cholesterol is of significant concern. Almost 76% of the entire group had levels of HDL below 40mg/dl. In addition it should be noted that a significant number of subjects have triglycerides (TG) above 150 mg/dl. Of the entire group 35.5% had values beyond this cut-off point. This lipid pattern: low HDL-high TG has previously been reported in Mexican population

ing the reported costs estimates for Mexican health care system, the issue of inefficacy is even more pressing and signals the need of a significant change of paradigm. This situation has been found in other parts the world.
The data regarding hypertension prevalence and con-
trol is significant. It signals that the issue is overall cardio-vascular risk, the small proportion of known hypertensives under appropriate hemodynamic control resembles the message that we see in diabetic subjects, that is, insuffi-cient effectiveness.
The information in Table IV, regarding the adherence 
of the providers to suggested care model or guideline, is of interest in several ways. Firstly it seems that there are less than expected situations in which the recommended behavior, was followed. Second the situation appears to be occurring in a similar fashion in all the institutions that encompass the Mexican Health Care System. This finding may be an area of opportunity to address efforts in order to maximize the adherence to the process. However the situation also suggest that, by simply following the recom-mended steps established by guidelines, there is no guar-antee the achievement of better metabolic control. What we do know is that, following the recommended steps at a guideline, there will be increments the costs of care. There-fore, it would seem unlikely to expect that the adherence to the recommendations will enhance the level of control.
The data summarized in this paper, gives the fourth 
element that adds onto the previous three that offers an apocalyptical scene: High prevalence, high lethality, high costs and high inefficiency. It seems likely that the de-scribed pattern, with some regional variants is occurring in other countries. This is indeed an area of opportunity for innovative research.

Health service users (HSUs) have a legitimate inter-
est in the provision of health care with a high level 
of quality as they are financial contributors, tax paying citizens and recipients of care.
1 However, public health 
services, particularly in developing countries, struggle to provide not only a high technical quality of care but also responsiveness to non-medical expectations.
2,3 As a result 
many HSUs, particularly in developing countries, prefer using fee-for-service care with high out-of-pocket expen-ditures. Hence, studying perceptions of quality of care is critical to understanding health service utilization. Because HSU perception of health services quality 
is a result of two principal factors: first, their experiences with access to care and use and second, the respective rat-ings or value they assign to these experiences, it has been argued that it is important to analyze both experiences and ratings simultaneously.
4-7 Reported experiences with 
access to health services include, among other aspects, transport time to the health service facility and the wait-ing time. Experiences with use include for example the physical examination by the physician, information pro-vided by the health care professional to the user and the length of consultation. The ratings include, for instance, how long the HSU perceived the travel time to be, wait-ing time at the facility (e.g. long or very long) and how they rate the information they received (very adequate or Ambulatory health service users’ experience of

focused only on patient’s satisfaction (e.g. the % of pa-tients satisfied with the waiting time) without taking into consideration the actual experience (e.g. length of waiting time) of access to and use of services.
8-11 The evaluation 
of patient’s satisfaction does not necessarily mean mea-suring of patient’s experiences as “satisfaction involves a cognitive evaluation of and emotional reaction to health care”
12 Hence, Coulter7 has argued that that it is central 
to measure patients’ experience in combination with their respective ratings. Information on both of these aspects is essential to improving quality in health services, as they can provide important reference points against which HSU experiences can be measured. As in other Latin America countries, insufficient 
quality of services and user dissatisfaction with the public and social security services have been cited as two of the main reasons why people in Mexico opt to use fee-for-services despite its financial implications. The use of fee-for-services among insured and uninsured population has increased over the last years in Mexico. In 2000 31.1% used fee-for-service,

using them.14 Fee-for-service care has been receiving the 
highest overall user satisfaction in recent years.15,13 To 
tackle insufficient quality of care, over the last decades 
the Mexican government has launched various initiatives to improve quality of care. Since 2007, the Comprehen-sive Quality System (Sistema Integral de Calidad or SI-Calidad) has aimed at quality improvement in the public sector. To make providers more accountable, HSU satis-faction with quality of services is reported periodically. For instance, in 2006 an average of 98% of ambulatory care patients were satisfied with the information received from the physician and 89% with the prescription filling.
16 
However, the data reported do not identify what experi-ences resulted in 11% of the HSUs reporting that they are not satisfied with their prescription filling (e.g. partial prescription filling, receiving no medicines or receiving inadequate information). Previous studies on user satisfaction with the qual-
ity of care comparing different service providers in Mex-ico reported that the primary reasons for perceived low quality were long waiting times and poor clinical exami-nation.
15 Other studies have focused on comparing in-
terpersonal quality of care between different health care providers in Mexico, which found that ambulatory health service HSUs were most frequently unsatisfied with the waiting times whereas hospitalized health service HSUs most frequently mentioned limited choice of provider as the reason for dissatisfaction.
17 A recent study by Puig et 
al18 focused on which health service user characteristics 
are associated with the perception of overall good qual-ity of health care and found that age, health status and education were associated with the overall perception of health care quality. Although these studies provide insight into the reasons why HSUs perceived the overall quality 
as low
15,17 or what HSU characteristics influence the per-
ception of good quality of care18 they do not provide in-
formation on which HSU experiences specifically resulted in a low quality rating and therefore, need to be improved. In other words, to give some examples, we need to know the average waiting time a HSU would rate as acceptable and what choice of providers is most frequently rated ac-ceptable. To improve health quality programs in Mexico and other countries this information is of high relevance. In addition, there is a paucity of information about which aspects of the experience of care most influenced the gen-eral perception of low quality when adjusting for patient characteristics. Such information would allow prioritizing in programs most relevant to HSUs. Therefore, the objec-tives of the present study were twofold: first to identify, on the bases of HSU experiences and their respective ratings of waiting time and expenditure on health care, reference points of acceptable quality and second, to analyze which HSU experiences are associated with a general perception of low health care quality.
Methods
The present study is based on an analysis of the most recent (2006) National Health and Nutrition Survey (ENSANUT) which has been carried out every six years since 1988 and explores the characteristics of household members in terms of health, physical activity, diet, chronic diseases and health service utilization.
19 The 2006 survey 
is a nationally representative, multistage, stratified sample of 47,152 households for which information was collected between October 2005 and May 2006.
19 (A rejection rate 
of approximately 15% has been taken into account when calculating the sample size.) For analysis purposes, infor-mation from the household and health ambulatory service utilization portion was used. In Mexico ambulatory health services (also called outpatient services) are defined as all diagnostic, curative and preventative services provided to individuals in and outside the hospital who depart after service delivery. This excludes hospital services (also called inpatient services) which are defined as those where in-dividuals receive diagnostics or curative services and stay for longer than 24 hours at the service delivery site (clinic or hospital). The HSU experiences instrument of EN-SANUT has been used in earlier national health services 1994 and 2000. A study testing for reliability and validity was carried out prior to their use.
15 The different aspects 
that the instruments include to analyze HSU experience are based on the literature of measuring quality of care.
20,21 
A random sample of household members was asked in a face-to-face interview about health service utilization in the previous 14 days and their experiences and perception in access and use of health services. HSUs were stratified according to the three main 
health care providers in Mexico: (1) Those attending Ministry of Health and related institutions (MOH) which comprises the Ministry of Health, Seguro Popu-lar, Comprehensive Family Development Program, Red Cross, Civil Hospital, National Institutions, and the social program Oportunidades; (2) Social Security Institutions (SSI) including the Mexican Institute of Social Security (IMSS), the Institute of Social Security and Services of State Workers (ISSSTE), Military Services (MARINA/DEFENSA), and Mexican Petrol (PEMEX); and (3) Ambulatory health service users’ experience of waiting time and expenditure and factors associated
