substantial decreases in antibiotic utilization. Policy chang-
es are also forces whose effects can be examined with these data. In Chile in 1999, the implementation of regulatory enforcement prohibiting sales of all antibiotics without a prescription in retail pharmacies, along with a mass media campaign, appeared to have major effects
(25). Although the 
initial success of this policy change on antibiotic use has been previously reported, our results show that these im-provements appear to have been short-lived and that the greatest impact of this policy occurred shortly after its in-troduction and during the next two years. Unfortunately, l 291 l
contributed to the change in utilization by improving ac-
cess to medicines via the public sectorÐ that is, increases in antibiotic utilization that might be totally appropriate? Nonetheless, understanding the utilization pattern and its trends can allow for more focused interventions or policy changes on improving antibiotic use and containing an-tibiotic resistance to be developed, as well as for assessing the impact of such interventions or policy changes. For example, evidence about increasing community antibiotic use was among the main forces to trigger the develop-ment of nationwide interventions in France and in Chile
(7, 
25). The large increase in Uruguay and the large decrease 
in Colombia observed in our study warrant further scru-tiny. The data also underline the need to be observant of the antibiotic-resistance patterns that could arise after the increasing consumption of some therapeutic classes, par-ticularly macrolides and quinolones.  Although we have based this report on data that repre-
sent the industry standard, there are significant limitations that one should consider. For each Latin American country in this study, there are no regularly collected, reliable data on the percentage of the population that obtains medicines through the retail (or government) sector. People with gov-ernment- sponsored insurance may purchase retail anti-biotics because of convenience and lack of supply in their governmentsponsored program
(27, 28). Conversely, some 
people without insurance obtain their medication from government institutions (which run their own pharmacies) that provide medication access to the poor. To address this limitation, we extrapolated utilization rates for the retail sector to the entire population for each country based on the proportion of a given country’s total medication mar-ket volume that was distributed via retail sector with data provided by the health care consultancy organization. This adjustment was most relevant for three countries (Mexico, Peru, and Colombia); for the other five countries in our study, the pharmaceutical retail volume covers more than 80% of the total sales volume in the country. Although the WHO ATC/DDD system is the lead-
ing consensus method to assess and compare antibiotic use, having been used widely for benchmarking and evaluat-ing the impact of intervene tion studies
(18), there are several 
limitations one must consider. The DDD as a technical unit does not reflect actual treatment dose or length of thera-py prescribed
(19). In addition, the DDD system cannot be 
applied to children, because it relates to an average adult weight
(17). Consequently, in many studies, liquid oral antibi-
otic preparations (intended for children) are excluded from the numerator. When children’s preparations are consid-ered (as in our study), it has been inferred that consumption is greater than what was estimated
(15). In addition to oral 
preparations, we included injectable preparations because they make up a considerable amount of total consumption. It is known that sales data are not equivalent to consump-tion as products purchased by pharmacies or by consum-ers might expire without having been taken; however, the information has been widely used as a proxy measure for medicine utilization at the population level. Our study analyzes utilization at the population level 
but did not account for differences in income or insurance coverage, which have been identified as factors influencing utilization in European countries
(9, 10). We found no clear 
association between country income level or insurance cov-erage and antibiotic consumption, except that the reduced income during the economic crisis in Argentina seems a very likely explanation for the reduced utilization between 1999 and 2003. More research is necessary to determine factors that can explain variations in antibiotic use in Latin America. Finally, in this study we do not present any cor-relation between antibiotic utilization and resistance pat-terns, which will be the subject of a separate analysis.
Conclusion
The substantial intercountry variation and increase in antibiotic consumption between 1997 and 2007 tie well into findings of escalating antibiotic resistance in Latin America
(29), which are being fueled by a combination of 
forces acting in concert: physicians who frequently pre-scribe antibiotics when they are not necessary, the public that demands antibiotics from doctors when they are not necessary or purchases antibiotics without a prescription, pharmacy staff inadequately trained to give sound advice for over-the-counter antibiotic purchases, and govern-ments that have no political will or economic resources for enforcing policies prohibiting antibiotic sales without a prescription and implementing interventions to improve antibiotic use
(11, 30±32). The European Union is funding 
ESAC, which aims to create policyrelevant evidence by analyzing and comparing antimicrobial consumption pat-terns across Europe
(33). A similar agency in Latin America 
would be important to foster policies aimed at improving appropriate use of antibiotics.

En esta sección, esbozaremos algunos de los conceptos 
generales que se esgrimen en los debates sobre el impacto de la investigación en la política sanitaria. Se define como «diseño de políticas» el ejercido por individuos que ocupan posiciones de autoridad en la toma de decisiones y gozan de una condición especial en el interior del grupo en que éstas inciden. Una perspectiva tan amplia del diseño de políticas
10 conlleva que los resultados puedan comprender 
múltiples formas, como políticas sanitarias diseñadas por gobiernos nacionales o locales, políticas sobre la utiliza-ción de recursos u organización asistencial diseñadas por las unidades que proporcionan asistencia local e, incluso, directrices clínicas implementadas por organismos profe-sionales. En evaluaciones de impacto o rentabilidad, esta acepción del término «diseño de políticas» conlleva gran-des ventajas en favor del impacto de la investigación en las políticas. No se ha convenido en una sola tipología de políticas, 
sino que hay varias categorizaciones que se consideran ade-cuadas para examinar la investigación sanitaria en relación con el diseño de políticas
11,12. Las tres categorías de polí-
ticas propuestas por Lomas Ð legislativas, administrativas y clínicasÐ  12 coinciden con la definición de diseño de políticas antes mencionada. Las políticas legislativas se re-
fieren al marco global que sirve para organizar los servicios sanitarios; las administrativas, al funcionamiento de estos 
servicios y a la asignación de recursos dentro del marco glo-bal, y, por último, las clínicas se refieren a los tratamientos que deben aplicarse. Es recomendable contemplar las cate-gorizaciones de políticas como una matriz donde distintos tipos de investigación tienen más probabilidad de impactar en determinadas categorías de políticas. Al analizar el diseño de políticas en relación con la 
utilización de la investigación, se suelen identificar al me-nos tres áreas de actividad amplias: el establecimiento de la agenda, la formulación y la implementación de la polí-tica
13. Potencialmente, la investigación tiene que ver con 
todas. Son numerosas las categorizaciones del diseño de 
políticas. Los modelos descritos aquí se basan en análisis anteriores
14,15. No se excluyen, sino que se incluyen mu-
tuamente, pues cada uno brinda una contribución parti-cular al análisis:Ð  Modelos racionales. Los modelos racionales de diseño de políticas suponen que los diseñadores identifican los problemas antes de revisar los datos sobre posibles soluciones y sus consecuencias para, al final, seleccionar la solución que mejor se ajusta a sus objetivos.
Ð  Modelos incrementalistas. No es apartir de ahora que el diseño de políticas se considera un proceso complejo. Puede implicar el conocimiento científico junto con una variedad de otros factores, incluidos intereses, valores, posiciones establecidas dentro de las insti-tuciones y ambiciones personales. En modelos como el «incrementalismo no conexionado»
16, el diseño de 
políticas no conlleva un movimiento claro hacia obje-tivos predeterminados; constituye más bien una serie de pasos pequeños en un proceso de «ingeniárselas»
17, 
o ir tomando «decisiones adicionales»18.
Ð  Redes. El modelo de redes subraya el papel de los diferentes intereses en el diseño y la forma en que las relaciones entre los grupos de intereses y los di-señadores de políticas pueden ocasionar un proceso de políticas incrementales. El análisis de los sistemas sanitarios indica que la profesión médica influye de forma poderosa en el diseño de las políticas en este sector
19. Incluso, el dominio que ésta ejerce en las re-
des políticas ha conducido al uso del término «red política profesionalizada»
20. Es probable que esta in-
fluencia sea un factor decisivo en el establecimiento de las agendas y la determinación del tipo de conoci-miento que predomina en los debates sobre políticas.
En esta categorización de diseño de políticas, se entiendepor qué hay la creencia que la investigación difícilmente puede producir un impacto significativo en las políticas. No obstante, en oposición a esta postura, se puede argu-mentar que las políticas basadas en la investigación serán siempre mejores que las que no lo están. Es evidente que la investigación expone el proceso de diseño a una mayor variedad de experiencias y conceptos validados que los que se manejan en los procesos normales de deliberación, li-mitados en el tiempo y políticamente constreñidos. Cier-tamente, la investigación conduce a la emisión de políticas con bases técnicamente informadas. En la presente cate-gorización, se mencionan las razones por las que algunas políticas han tenido éxito y otras no. Además, se pueden apreciar los vínculos entre factores que normalmente se perciben como separados, como la naturaleza del campo sustancial y los patrones organizativos que se han estable-cido para controlarlo, así como el poder del entorno sobre las condiciones sanitarias

 A raíz del trabajo de Weiss22 y otros21,23,24, se han 
identificado diversos modelos de utilización de investi-
gación para el diseño de políticas, cada uno aplicable en diferente momento del diseño.
Ð  El modelo clásico/purista/guiado por el conocimiento. Si -
gue una secuencia lineal, donde la investigación gene-
ra conocimientos que impulsan la acción.
Ð  El modelo de solución de problemas/ingeniería/guiado por la política. También sigue una secuencia lineal, 
pero comienza con la identificación de un problema por un cliente que solicita a un investigador identifi-car y valorar soluciones.
Ð  El modelo interactivo/interacción social. Trata de un 
conjunto de interacciones entre investigadores y usuarios, más que un movimiento lineal desde la in-vestigación hasta la toma de decisiones. Garantiza que cada uno esté expuesto al entorno y a las necesi-dades de los demás.
Ð  El modelo de la ilustración/colación/«piedra caliza». Aquí es probable que la investigación se utilice como una «sedimentación» gradual de perspicacia, teorías, conceptos y diferentes puntos de vista. Este modelo ofrece la ventaja de ampliar el abanico de vías para utilizar la investigación.
Ð  El modelo político. Aquí los hallazgos son argumentos en un sistema adverso de diseño de políticas.
Ð  El modelo táctico. La investigación se utiliza cuando hay presiones para que se implementen acciones en relación con un tema y los diseñadores de políticas responden anunciando que han encargado un estudio de investigación al respecto.
Hay puntos de convergencia, más no una correspondencia absoluta, entre las características principales de los mo-delos de diseño de políticas aquí analizados y los diversos procesos de utilización de investigación. Weiss indica que se puede concebir y utilizar la investigación para el diseño de políticas de tres maneras fundamentales: a) como datos y hallazgos; b) como ideas y críticas bajo el modelo aquí ilustrado, o c) como resúmenes y argumentos para tomar acción
25. Además, la utilización de la investigación en el 
diseño de políticas puede considerarse instrumental, con-ceptual o simbólica
13. El uso instrumental implica que los 
hallazgos se utilizan directamente en el diseño; el concep-tual se refiere a cómo se utilizan y, por último, en el sim-bólico, la investigación se utiliza para apoyar una posición ya establecida, que puede ser incluso la de mantener las políticas actuales. Se considera cada vez más importante agrupar los hallazgos de los estudios individuales en revi-siones sistemáticas, con el fin de proporcionar evidencia más contundente para el diseño de políticas
26.
 Del análisis de conceptos generales arriba expuesto se 
desprende que la investigación puede influir en las políti-cas sanitarias de muchas maneras, y que la evaluación de los diferentes niveles de impacto puede constituir una tarea compleja, la cual examinaremos en detalle a continuación.
Revisión de estudios que abarcan las 
condiciones previas al impacto de la investigación
Muchos análisis se han centrado en los obstáculos a los 
intentos de utilizar la investigación en el diseño de políti-
cas. La revisión referida en este artículo ha logrado iden-tificar específicamente las evaluaciones de programas de investigación sanitaria que han tenido más impacto (tanto en la política como en la práctica y ganancia sanitarias) y que se han publicado en inglés
1. Durante esta revisión 
se identificaron 17 programas de investigación, cada cual con múltiples proyectos. En promedio, la proporción de proyectos por programa fue alta, y se detectaron sólo tres programas en los cuales menos del 30% de sus proyectos había logrado algún impacto. En algunos casos, los pro-gramas eran evaluaciones de tecnología sanitaria (ETS), donde prácticamente todos los proyectos de investiga-ción influyeron en las políticas. De hecho, varios estudios abordaron el impacto del programa ETS en Quebec
27,28, 
donde todos los proyectos influyeron en la política: uno de ellos condujo a un aumento en la detección sistemática de cáncer de mama, y otro, a una reducción en las radiogra-fías torácicas preoperatorias habituales28. Hubo estudios incluidos en la revisión que utilizaron el Modelo Payback de Buxton y Hanney
23, que indicó que entre el 30 y el 
50% de los proyectos habían ejercido algún impacto en las políticas. Se analizaron también estudios sobre el impacto de 
programas de investigación publicados posteriormente a la fecha tope, para incluirlos en la revisión antes mencio-nada. Entre ellos figura la evaluación de rentabilidad de la investigación financiada por TV3 Telethon en Cataluña, la cual mostró que efectivamente la investigación había producido un impacto en la política
29. En otro estudio 
realizado en la Escuela de Salud e Higiene Tropical de l 297 l
Londres se concluyó que los estudios de caso «habían des-
tacado una amplia variedad de áreas en las que la investi-gación había tenido influencia en los servicios sanitarios y en las políticas»
30. Por ejemplo, uno de los proyectos 
influyó en la política del Instituto Nacional de Salud y Excelencia Clínica con respecto a técnicas quirúrgicas para la amigdalectomía; y otro sobre la morbimortalidad asociada a la temperatura en el hogar influyó en la legis-lación sobre viviendas en el Reino Unido
30. Por último, la 
evaluación de rentabilidad del programa de Evaluación de Tecnología Sanitaria en el Reino Unido detectó numero-sas políticas clínicas relacionadas con la investigación de los programas evaluados
1. Un ensayo controlado y alea-
torizado de 3 estrategias de tratamiento y rehabilitación de ictus
31 influyó en las directrices clínicas nacionales re-
ferentes a la provisión de especialistas en las unidades de ictus: algunas establecidas por el Colegio Real de Médicos en Inglaterra
32 y otras por la Red Escocesa Intercolegial 
de Lineamientos33. Entre las técnicas empleadas por los 
estudios de impacto de la investigación, incluidos en la revisión antes mencionada, figuran: análisis de contenido, encuestas, entrevistas y estudios de casos
1. Al considerar 
por qué estos estudios indicaron un impacto mayor que muchos análisis en el pasado, se detectó que la mayoría de ellos contenían probables fuentes de sesgo: muchos los patrocinó la organización que había financiado la inves-tigación en primer lugar, y algunos los habían realizado investigadores de esa organización. Además, muchas de las fuentes de datos empleadas se obtuvieron, al menos parcialmente, de investigadores que participaron en los proyectos evaluados
1.
 Hay, sin embargo, buenas razones por las que la ma-
yoría de las evaluaciones incluidas en esta revisión repor-taron un impacto mayor que muchos estudios anteriores
1. 
En primer lugar, como criterio de inclusión en la revi-sión, las evaluaciones debían realizarse desde un programa identificable de investigación. Esto proporciona un foco más estrecho que otros estudios que comienzan analizan-do un área de política o desarrollo, y luego retroceden para evaluar el impacto de alguna investigación. Los estudios que indagan hacia delante tienen más probabilidad de captar cualquier impacto de investigación en el proceso de diseño de la política, por muy reducido que éste sea. Además, muchos de los estudios provienen de programas de evaluación de tecnologías y de investigación sanitaria aplicada, donde el papel del receptor (o cliente) en la re-cepción y la utilización de la investigación suele ser un factor importante a favor del impacto
1.El modelo de «interfases y receptor»
para evaluar el impacto de la investigación
En el análisis realizado en el Reino Unido hace más de 
25 años por Kogan y Henkel9,21, se indicó que en los casos 
donde se utiliza investigación en el diseño de políticas es deseable aplicar, aunque resulte difícil de lograr, un méto-do de colaboración entre diseñadores e investigadores. En este análisis se indican los problemas relacionados con los límites o las interfases clave, y se describen algunos pasos necesarios para conseguir un impacto mayor de la investi-gación, como el desarrollo de los agentes del conocimien-to y el fortalecimiento de la capacidad de los organismos receptores para recibir los hallazgos de la investigación. Esta corriente de investigación la desarrollaron los colegas de Kogan y Henkel para elaborar el denominado Modelo Payback
23.
 Al valorar el impacto de la investigación, es útil dispo-
ner de un marco de trabajo conceptual para organizar los instrumentos de recolección de datos y las explicaciones reportadas. El Modelo Payback proporciona este entor-no y el modelo de «interfases y receptor» lo complementa cuando el foco del estudio se refiere al impacto de la inves-tigación en las políticas
6. Sin embargo, este modelo va aún 
más lejos: no sólo ayuda a identificar los factores relevan-tes a la consecución del impacto, sino que también ofrece un modelo preceptivo en cuanto a formas de aumentar la rentabilidad a partir de la investigación sanitaria.
El modelo de «interfases y receptor»:
el papel de las interfases
El concepto de interfases facilita el análisis de los asuntos 
que surgen en la relación entre diseñadores de políticas e investigadores
23. En primer lugar, es útil cuando los in-
vestigadores y los diseñadores pertenecen a dos culturas o comunidades con diferentes valores, idioma, sistemas de gratificación y afiliaciones sociales y profesionales
34, lo 
que a veces implica dificultades para interactuar de forma constructiva. En segundo lugar, contribuye al análisis de la idea generalizada de que los diseñadores de políticas y los investigadores manejan diferentes escalas de tiempo. Esto lo describió claramente el Dr. Julio Frenk antes de su nombramiento como secretario de Salud de México, al afirmar que los diseñadores de políticas son cronofóbi-cos y los investigadores, cronofílicos
35. En tercer lugar, el 
concepto de permeabilidad en las interfases23 contribuye Evaluación del impacto de la investigación

a nuestro análisis en el sentido siguiente: si bien es cierto 
que los diseñadores necesitan animar a los investigadoresa que acepten y comprendan sus problemas, es deseable que estos últimos mantengan cierto grado de imper-meabilidad, o autonomía, sobre asuntos como sus méto-dos de investigación. Hay muchas interfases indirectas; sin embargo, aquí 
describiremos los enlaces directos entre el sistema de in-vestigación sanitario y los diseñadores de políticas. En pri-mer lugar, la interfase del establecimiento de prioridades, de la evaluación de necesidades y de la contratación de investigación. En segundo, la interfase de la diseminación y transferencia del conocimiento. El establecimiento de prioridades suele funcionar de forma más efectiva cuando hay una lista de intereses, de manera que los diseñadores de políticas puedan expresar cuáles son sus demandas y los investigadores, definir qué es investigable. También es útil el método iterativo
6. El método de colaboración es 
considerado importante y se facilita cuando hay comités de diseñadores de políticas e investigadores de largo pla-zo. En esta interfase, es recomendable emplear un méto-do para potenciar la síntesis de evidencia a fin de que los diseñadores involucren a los investigadores en la revisión de pruebas antes de establecer las prioridades. Es posible que los investigadores no estén dispuestos a trabajar en una agenda con la que no concuerdan, o que propongan proyectos que desvían las intenciones originales de los diseñadores. Es más factible lograr un compromiso por parte de los investigadores cuando éstos se involucran en el establecimiento de las prioridades. Centros de investi-gación con financiamiento a largo plazo pueden facilitar, de manera importante, la interacción entre diseñadores e investigadores, y ayudar a precisar las percepciones de cada uno6. Mediante su concepto de «vinculación e in-tercambio», Lomas plantea argumentos hacia un contacto mayor entre ambos grupos durante todas las etapas del proceso de investigación
36.
 En la interfase de comunicaciones o de transferencia 
de conocimiento, hay mecanismos que favorecen la per-meabilidad entre los actores; entre ellos, los resúmenes de políticas por parte de los investigadores y la utilización de la investigación o de agentes de conocimiento que tomen los hallazgos de los investigadores y ayuden a transferir-los a los diseñadores de las políticas
21,23. Los comités de 
especialistas a largo plazo en los que diseñadores e inves-tigadores trabajan conjuntamente facilitan la transferencia de hallazgos, así como los centros de investigación antes mencionados.El modelo de «interfases y receptor»: el papel 
de los receptores
La idea de los diseñadores de las políticas como receptores 
de los hallazgos de investigación6,13,21 encaja con el con-
cepto de «utilización en escalera» de tales hallazgos37, en 
el que la utilización de la investigación en el diseño de po-líticas representa una serie de escalones. Éstos comienzan con los asuntos de la interfase de transmisión de hallazgos a los diseñadores y avanzan hacia los asuntos del receptor, incluidas la absorción y la revisión sistemática de pruebas, así como su utilización en el diseño. Aunque los recepto-res son los responsables de estas funciones, el sistema de investigación puede participar facilitando el uso de la in-vestigación por medio de mecanismos, como la capacita-ción para la realización de revisiones sistemáticas. El éxito del papel de receptor está ligado a diversos factores, como la creación de sistemas que garanticen que las prioridades establecidas reflejen las necesidades de los diseñadores. Otro factor es el desarrollo de vínculos a largo plazo que aporten a estos diseñadores una visión realista de la in-vestigación. Posiblemente, lo más importante sea atender de forma cuidadosa los asuntos de capacitación, cultura y estructuras organizativas de los organismos receptores
6,9.
Aplicación del modelo de «interfases y 
receptor»
Hay un plan ya desarrollado para implementar el modelo 
de interfases y receptor6, que sirve también para identi-
ficar los factores que contribuyen a que la investigación produzca un impacto. A continuación se analizan dos ca-sos concretos.
Impacto de un proyecto en la carrera de mujeres médicas en el 
Reino Unido. Este proyecto
38 incluyó acciones clave en las 
interfases. El Departamento de Sanidad del Reino Unido fungió como organismo receptor y trabajó con el investi-gador para desarrollar el proyecto en la interfase de espe-cificaciones y asignación de la comisión de investigación. Una vez concluido el proyecto, en la interfase de disemi-nación, el ministro de Sanidad contribuyó en la venta de los hallazgos al personal clínico, y en una reunión organi-zada para comunicar estos hallazgos comentó que éstos tenían enormes implicaciones para la política del Gobier-no y para la profesión médica en sí
39. Otro funcionario 
clave con antigüedad en el Departamento de Sanidad se l 299 l
involucró también, y promovió la aceptación del informe. 
En un tema de esta envergadura, se consideró una gran variedad de evidencia y los hallazgos de este proyecto for-maron parte de un amplio movimiento a favor de la po-lítica en cuestión
39. El modelo de «interfases y receptor» 
ayudó a analizar este caso e identificar los factores que incidieron en el impacto logrado.
El caso de la investigación de los sistemas de salud en Méxi-
co. En 1994, la Fundación Mexicana para la Salud 
(FUNSALUD), siendo el Dr. Julio Frenk vicepresidente, publicó un estudio denominado «Salud y Economía» en torno a una serie de herramientas, incluidas las cuentas nacionales de salud, los análisis de rentabilidad de un pa-quete de intervenciones esenciales en salud y un mapa de las políticas de salud. El patronato de la Fundación finan-ció este estudio por un total de medio millón de dóla-res, duró dos años, y contó con una nutrida participación de decisores e investigadores tanto del ámbito nacional, como internacional. Un consejo consultivo internacional, formado por investigadores y diseñadores de políticas de alto nivel, apoyaron el establecimiento de prioridades para la investigación y la supervisión de los resultados. Los re-sultados se difundieron de forma amplia mediante diarios, resúmenes de políticas, resúmenes ejecutivos, un informe detallado y una propuesta de políticas. Este esfuerzo produjo beneficios inmediatos que se 
registraron en diversos niveles, a saber: se fortaleció la capa-cidad de investigación y dentro de FUNSALUD se insti-tucionalizó el Centro de Estudios de Economía y Salud, el cual ha seguido produciendo bases de datos y análisis rele-vantes al esfuerzo original. También se estableció el Centro de Referencia Internacional de Iniciativas de Reforma del Sector Salud, como interfase entre los investigadores y los diseñadores de políticas involucrados en esta reforma. Por otra parte, el secretario de Salud continúo adoptando re-comendaciones referentes a las políticas, especialmente en cuanto al desarrollo de fórmulas para asignar recursos a par-tir de la equidad. Sin embargo, el impacto más importante del estudio Economía y Salud no se constató hasta el año 2003, cuando México implantó el Sistema de Protección Social en Salud (SPSS), un esfuerzo de reducción de gastos catastróficos en salud mediante la ampliación universal del seguro de salud, dirigido por el Dr. Frenk, ya en su cargo de secretario de Salud federal. Para entonces, la Secretaría de Salud había institucionalizado las cuentas sanitarias nacio-nales y los diseñadores de políticas habían desarrollado una gran destreza en su aplicación. El SPSS se formuló a raíz de los desequilibrios financieros arrojados por las cuentas sa-nitarias nacionales, incluidos los índices bajos de inversión, la elevada proporción del gasto en salud destinada al pago de sueldos y las desigualdades financieras entre los diversos grupos poblacionales. Los análisis de rentabilidad de este proyecto ayudaron a justificar un paquete de intervenciones esenciales de salud. En este caso, el apoyo y las pruebas de la investigación 
ayudaron a convencer al Congreso de México de que la in-versión en el SPSS era sensata y fiscalmente, responsable. Sobre esta base, el Congreso autorizó incrementar el pre-supuesto del SPSS por un punto porcentual del producto interior bruto entre los años 2004 y 2010, a fin de lograr la cobertura universal del seguro. Por otra parte, las polí-ticas se beneficiaron tanto de inversiones en investigación basadas en las plataformas y herramientas de este estudio, como de estudios posteriores orientados a precisar las esti-maciones sobre políticas, valorar los procesos y evaluar los resultados logrados por él a la fecha. Como consecuencia, la diferencia entre el gasto en salud per cápita de los bene-ficiarios de seguridad social en el sector formal frente al de los beneficiarios del SPSS en el sector informal disminuyó de 2,44 en 2003 a 1,75 en 2006. El estudio del caso de México ilustra tanto los gra-
dos de influencia y rentabilidad que la investigación puede alcanzar, como las escalas de tiempo en que éstos se pueden producir. La investigación de los sistemas de salud ayudó al secretario de Salud, como rector del siste-ma de salud mexicano, a ganar confianza en un régimen democrático. Se puede afirmar que el aumento de pre-supuesto citado y su impacto en la equidad constituyen un indicador claro de que resulta rentable invertir en la investigación sobre los sistemas de salud a medio pla-zo. Además, el caso de México ilustra los beneficios que brinda la estabilidad de las políticas en cuanto a garan-tizar la madurez de las inversiones en la investigación. A corto plazo, aunque muchas decisiones se han tomado en un marco de trabajo racional, con el tiempo, ha aparecido una red de políticas basadas en la evidencia y tendientes a ella. La comunicación que se abrió, e incluso la «puer-ta giratoria» que se evidenció, entre las comunidades de investigadores y diseñadores de políticas de ámbito nacional e internacional ha sido una interfase crítica en este sentido. Esto conlleva un riesgo de fuga de cerebros, pero, a la vez, ofrece una oportunidad para aumentar las interacciones y potenciar la toma de decisiones a partir de la evidencia, sobre todo cuando el diseñador de las políticas ha sido el propio investigador.

Conclusiones
A pesar de las interacciones complejas y variadas que hay
entre la investigación y el diseño de políticas, se puede identificar un número mayor de casos de investigación con impacto en políticas de lo que se suele creer. Y este campo se está desarrollando constantemente con inves-tigaciones nuevas e importantes que amplían el rango de las evidencias40. El modelo conceptual de las «interfases y receptor» ofrece un marco de trabajo útil para organizar los estudios de impacto, y analizar de forma empírica los factores susceptibles de aumentar las posibilidades de su-perar algunas de las dificultades más relevantes en el logro de un impacto, y así incrementar la incidencia de la inves-tigación en el diseño de las políticas.

The National Institute of Public Health in Mexico 
(Instituto Nacional de Salud Pública, INSP), an in-
stitution devoted to public health and nutrition research, has defined its vocation as research conducted with the aim of improving health conditions in the population. This type of research, referred to by Frenk as “research with a mission”,
1 has been defined as “the development 
of a research effort to modify reality through producing knowledge and technology”. The “mission” is precisely that change in reality. The aim of research with a mission in public health 
is to improve the health conditions of the population through application of the scientific method to the study of several objects and levels of analysis. The objects are the health conditions and the organized social response (poli-cies, programs, and actions) for preventing and controlling those conditions. The levels of analysis include subcel-lular particles (molecular biology), individuals (clinical research), populations (epidemiological research), and health systems (systems research). A multidisciplinary ap-proach is used in order to generate knowledge directed toward solving the public health challenges. An important aspect of research with a mission is the use of scientific evidence for decision-making in public health, including that which affects the design and evaluation of health and nutrition policies.Improving nutrition in Mexico:
the use of  research for decision making*
Juan A Rivera.(1)
 The Centre for Research on Nutrition and Health 
(Centro de Investigación en Nutrición y Salud or CINyS) at INSP , inspired by the philosophy of research with a mission, has developed a guideline for defining the re-search agenda at CINyS. The research sequence as applied to malnutrition 
problems (Figure 1) starts with a study of the nutritional 
conditions (magnitude and distribution of malnutrition problems in the population and its determinants) and the social responses (policies and programs with potential im-pact on malnutrition), and it continues with the following investigations: studies about the functional consequences or health impact of malnutrition on populations in or-der to determine the relevance of the problems; studies about the etiology and the social and biological mecha-nisms of malnutrition; studies about the design and test-ing of small-scale actions or interventions; efficacy studies (conducted under controlled conditions of delivery and utilization of interventions); and effectiveness studies or large-scale program evaluations conducted under regular program operating conditions and including evaluations of the process and cost-effectiveness of interventions. Effectiveness studies to evaluate 
actions and programs
Presented here is information on the evaluation of the ef-
fectiveness of the program Oportunidades and its impact 
on the nutritional status of participating children.2 The 
benefits provided by the program include the distribution of a micronutrient-fortified food supplement, which was specifically designed to meet nutrient deficits in infants 6±23 months of age. The program initially included approximately 300,000 
homes. As it was not possible at that time to immedi-ately cover the total target population, an evaluation study was planned with a randomized design. Several locali-ties were randomly assigned to one of two interventions, the first one consisting of receiving program benefits for 2 years, and the second consisting of receiving benefits after 2 years, when the study was concluded. The study design was followed rigorously for the first year (1998±1999). Nevertheless, although it was unplanned, both groups received the benefits of the program in the period 1999±2000. For this reason, the group that received the benefits of the program from the beginning was deemed the intervention group, while the other, which received the benefits only in the second year, was classified as the “crossover intervention group”, as it started out as a con-trol group but later became the intervention group dur-ing the second year. Despite the change in the original study design, it was still possible to evaluate the effects of the program over 2 years, since the intervention group received the benefits for 2 years, while the crossover inter-vention sample received them for half the time. Moreover, the intervention group received the benefits during the critical first two years of life, while the crossover interven-tion group did not receive benefits during a substantial part of that period. The greatest impact was expected for infants younger than 6 months in 1988, reflecting those who belonged to the intervention group that received the benefits of the program during the critical first 2 years of life. In contrast, those infants in the crossover intervention group received benefits for only 1 year, starting at 12±18 months of age; thus, they did not receive benefits during most of the critical period. It was also expected that the greatest effects would be found in children from the low-est income level, since the prevalence of malnutrition was greatest in that group. For these reasons, all comparisons were made after groups were stratified by age (<6 months and 6±12 months at enrollment) and socioeconomic level (lower than average or higher than average). Decentralization has been defined as the transfer of 
authority for parastatal organizations, local govern-
ments and non-governmental organizations (Rondinelli and Cheema 1983). This strategy has been promoted by various governments and agencies in developing countries as part of administrative reforms seeking equity and ef-ficiency. These measures follow the belief that excessive centralization increases economic and social costs, as well as being a source of political disturbance (World Bank 1987). The World Health Organization thus sees decen-tralization as a means of achieving greater coordination and responsiveness to local needs through delegation of responsibility, authority and resources to the community and to intermediate levels (WHO 1980). Generally, de-centralization has been praised as a means, of obtaining community participation and promoting local responsi-bility for health (Mills et at. 1987). Decentralization is not a clear-cut concept and is 
fraught with ambiguity. Thus, what at one level may be seen as administrative decentralization, at another may imply greater power to the central political authorities. This is particularly the case with the form of decentral-ization called delegation, where anew, parastatal organ-ism is created at the margin of the central bureaucracy. Through circumventing central bureaucratic interests and social and political pressures, delegation may enhance the Health services decentralization in Mexico:

 This article explores the technical and political moti-
vations of health service decentralization in Mexico, and 
assesses its implications for the areas of finance, plan-ning and health service delivery and equity. The focus is on the shortterm results of decentralization in the most underdeveloped region of the country -the south -a re-gion comparable with the central American countries and other least-developed nations in the world.
Centralization and fragmentation of 
the health sector
Health service centralization in Mexico was a phenome-
non closely tied to the phase of import substitution in the economy that started with the Second World War. Health policy supported economic growth through abstract, tech-nical approaches far removed from peasant organizations and closer to the vertical, corporatist industrial leadership. The Ministry of Sanitation and Assistance (SSA), and the Mexican Institute of Social Security (IMSS), were cre-ated to implement these policies through greater federal finance and control. Indeed SSA went on to build hospi-tals nationwide entirely dependent on federal monies and decisions, thus bringing down state governments’ finance from 50% to less than 10%. Although the social security institute was formally decentralized as a tripartite para-statal organism, the federation maintained firm political control and used it as a powerful negotiating tool control-ling capital and labour. From the early 1970s Mexico faced a stagnant econ-
omy, greater social inequalities and widespread discontent with government. The political crisis led central authori-ties to press against the industrialists with a policy of ‘social solidarity’ through which the IMSS would collaborate with the federal government to provide medical and preventive care to the organized peasantry. However, the IMSS was also charged with implementing the programme through its own autonomous administration, without any control by the Ministry of Health or participation from local com-munities. It is no surprise, then, that once political pressure eased, the programme was all but terminated, bringing fi-nancing down from 1.3% of the Institute’s budget in 1976, to 0.3% in 1979 (Spalding 1980). From the late 1970s centralization and fragmentation 
started to be seen as a political liability. However, poverty was becoming an ever more threatening issue, leading with the oil boom to a new wave of centralization, this time combined with mild efforts of central and regional coordination. On the one hand delegated institutions were strengthened and coordinated at the presidential level through a special body, called COPLAMAR; on the other hand, federal planning was deconcentrated through state-level planning committees (COP LADES), where federal delegates were motivated to coordinate through tying part of their budget to state-level consolidated de-velopment agreements (CUD). Centralization and fragmentation in health policy 
deepened as IMSS participated through COPLAMAR in a drive towards health service extension for the rural poor. IMSS was chosen for its capacity to plan and deliver more than 3000 clinics ill the most dispersed areas of the country, all in less than two years. The programme was to be financed wholly through federal funds, and would not link up with the urban worker’s infrastructure. Fur-thermore, it did not imply any legal or financial respon-sibilities for redistributive social solidarity. However, the programme was mounted on the same tracks and with the same social solidarity image as the previous programme, giving a boost to the Institute’s welfare role without any of its previous costs. The new wave of centralization meant that health is-
sues and planning were left out of the regional coordina-tion bodies, furthering the fragmentation and redundancy between IMSS and SSA. On the other hand, most of SSA’s delegates were not able to participate in the complex coordination procedures at the state level and were thus not able to profit from the monies distributed through the COPLADES. Only the most developed states were able to benefit, turning the instruments of integral rural development into a regressive mechanism.
Health service decentralization in the 
1980s 
The government of Miguel de la Madrid came to power in 
1982 at the beginning of the deepest recession in the his-tory of modern Mexico. Between the end of the oil boom in 1982 and the last year of de la Madrid’s administration the per capita health budget was thus reduced by 48.00/0. These cuts particularly affected the insured population which increased from 44.6% of the national population in 1982 to 52.1 % in 1987. This group saw its per capita health expenditures reduced by 15.7% per annum between 1983 and 1987, while the open population budget remained about constant. In all, the per capita health budget differen-tial between the two groups was reduced from 3.62 to 1.39. This trend was to constitute an important obstacle towards l 309 l
the policies of sectorization and decentralization pursued 
by the new Ministry of Health.
President de la Madrid used Mexican constitutional 
federalism as a ready-made charter for deep political re-form, positing devolution, deconcentration and fiscal re-form as the chief strategies to strengthen the basic units of government (Beltran and Portilla 1986). All this was to be more firmly coordinated by the minister of planning and budgeting, who was also supposed to devolve authority to the governors to coordinate the state-level field offices cre-ated in the previous administration. The state government’s development plans were thus incorporated for the first time into an overall scheme, enabling a massing of financial re-sources to meet the economic crisis.
In his role as the previous minister for planning bud-
geting, de la Madrid had become preoccupied with the incapacity to provide good quality governmental health services within a well co-ordinated scheme, and recognized that a root cause of the problem was the accretion of various institutions into an unmanageable health sector. He created a health services coordination group to study alternatives for a national health system capable of reaching the 14 mil-lion then considered to be without any services, in order to achieve universal coverage. The main recommendations of the group were to couple sectorization and decentralization to achieve a strong health authority capable of transform-ing vices accumulated after decades of centralized fragmen-tation (Soberón 1987). 
Those threatened by sectorization tried to thwart any 
attempts towards integration, and before the policy recom-mendations were adopted the leader of the Confederation of Mexican Workers forced through a mild definition of ‘integration’ with a formula of programmatic co-ordination which would guarantee the autonomy of IMSS. Further-more, the social security institute proposed lessening frag-mentation through a fusion of all federally funded rural health services around IMSS’s own, more efficient and qualitatively superior social solidarity infrastructure. This motion was questioned by the group, arguing that it would deepen the urban-rural duality.
 Conscious of the formidable obstacles to bring about 
reform at the central level, the health services coordina-tion group established planning agreements with 20 state governors through the state-level planning bodies. These agreements enabled the analysts to obtain information, ideas and support for sectoral integration at the source of the problems and beyond the centralist sources of power of the national institutions. Fragmentation at the centre was thus combated with decentralization at the periphery. President elect de la Madrid adopted the proposal 
of the health services coordination group and prepared a national health law and a constitutional amendment to establish health as a universal right. The new charters were a means to legitimate the role of SSA as sectoral head pave the way to the establishment of the national health system. However, this situation threatened IMSS, as the institute would lose power over its prestigious social soli-darity programme, thus opening the door for redistribu-tory demands such as had occurred in the early 1970s. To avoid losing power and autonomy, IMSS acted 
early in the administration to comply with the philoso-phy of sectorization and decentralization under its own schemes. IMSS thus implemented its own deconcentra-tion plans through widening the participation of its state-level Social Solidarity Boards to the Ministry of Health and other federal agencies. This channelled the drive to-wards decentralization away from fusion and devolution and towards more technical, paternalistic and counselling participation of the federal government within its social solidarity programme. IMSS also vehemently argued that SSA would not be capable of managing the social solidar-ity infrastructure, and that the final result of integrative decentralization was bound to be negative. Facing strong opposition against both sectorization 
and decentralization, SSA set about formulating pilot projects for devolution, as well as streamlining its organic structure to play the role as normative head of the health sector. As a preliminary step to fully fledged decentral-ization, SSA deconcentrated all its field offices by giving them greater managerial responsibilities, such as planning and budgeting. By 1984 many rival approaches towards decentraliza-
tion had been formulated both by SSA and IMSS, thus threatening inaction. This led to a presidential decree stat-ing for the first time, and thus compelling, the fusion of the social solidarity programme with services provided by SSA to create new organisms under the authority of the state governments and the normative control of the ministry (Diario OficiaI1984). Yet only 14 states reached such a stage by the end of the administration, I accounting in all for approximately 40% of the non-insured popula-tion residing outside the Federal District (which did not decentralize) and which had 45% of the health resources (Dirección General de Evaluación 1987). Some of the factors that played a part in the decision 
to decentralize complied with the dynamics of interinsti-tutional rivalry. Indeed, the most outstanding fact behind implementation was that most of the devolved states were

This meant that IMSS was able to maintain 72% of it health centres and retain coverage of 6.5 million people. Implementation of decentralization was also favoured in states that had already achieve, greater financial decen-tralization for diverse historical reasons. Thus, prior to implementation the states chosen contributed an aver-age of 17.43% of health expenditures, while those that were to remain centralized gave only 5.58% Basically, the Ministry aimed to decentralize those states where least resistance was met from both the social security institute and the local governors. As well as the influences analysed above, the imple-
mentation of decentralization also had a direct relationship to centralist political control, and an inverse relationship to the pull of local or regional opposition forces. This was clearly demonstrated with the comparable states of Oax-aca and Guerrero. Oaxaca was the first state scheduled for decentralization, yet the decision was aborted in its early stages. The decision to try for early decentralization was an attempt that failed -to use the strategy to co-opt a statewide autonomist movement which was getting out of control after years of localized ferment (Rubin 1987). Health service decentralization seemed to promise the governor both the flexibility to handle resources accord-ing to his political needs, whilst giving him the image of autonomy required to co-opt those groups which ques-tioned centralist dominance. However, as the conflict es-calated, the strong and well-tried centralist muscle was used to quell the conflicts, while decentralization came to be seen by SSA as more of a risk than an asset. The decision to abort decentralization in Oaxaca 
was welcomed by IMSS, as the institute stood to lose the greatest concentration of clinics in the social soli-darity programme. Those in the Ministry of Health also sighed with relief at this decision, as they perceived the great complexities involved in decentralizing services that catered for a highly dispersed, unconsulted ethnic population. All this indicates that decentralization was not perceived to be the best medicine for Oaxaca, a very underdeveloped state. Although Guerrero shared the same socioeconomic 
indicators and a similar number of social solidarity units as Oaxaca, decentralization was perceived there as highly plausible. Significantly, both the health minister and his planning under-secretary were natives of this state and strong candidates for becoming governor, a post finally assumed by the latter shortly after the implementation of decentralization. This evidence points to the highly cen-tralist nature of the policy of decentralization, in spite of the official reference to the ‘political will’ of governors as the driving force behind policy implementation. The interruption of the implementation of decen-
tralization and its with holdment from 14 states, can be partlyoexplained as the result of pressures from IMSS to maintain the solidarity programme under its control, although the deepening of the economic crisis in 1985, and the incapacity to provide the needed incentives, also played their part. The decision to interrupt decentraliza-tion occurred when IMSS complained of the deterioration of services in the rural areas of the state of Guerrero -the state with the greatest number of social solidarity clinics that the institute had lost. IMSS seized on the opportuni-ty to press their claim for interruption by going directly to the president, who then ordered an immediate evaluation. IMSS was able to convince the highest authorities that the changes in service indicators were the direct result of the new state health authority’s incapacity to cope with decentralization, a view reaffirmed by the rather localized popular protest that also emerged. The president thus or-dered decentralization to stop until both the Ministry of Health and IMSS jointly submitted a detailed evaluation that could lead to a remedy to the problems. Meanwhile, the services in the decentralized states were to be con-solidated, while the remainder would pursue further pro-grammatic co-ordination to avoid deterioration following decentralization.
The results of decentralization 
Implementation of decentralization is still an ongoing process, and discussing its outcomes in health is prema-ture. However, the structural change that occurred af-fected the delivery of services in ways that may well get misconstrued in final ‘analyses. We will therefore focus on selected variables as indicators of the structural and processual changes attributable to decentralization. To this end a methodology was adopted that allowed com-parison of decentralized and centralized states within a given socioeconomic region of the country, a possibil-ity that resulted from the policy interruption discussed above. Through such a comparison the effects of the eco-nomic crisis could be separated from those attributable to decentralization. The socio-economic region chosen was the poor-
est in the country. It contains the decentralized state of Guerrero and the centralized state of Oaxaca.² This region tests the adequacy of and obstacles against decentralized l 311 l
health planning and management in a particularly poor 
and underdeveloped region. It has been argued that under these conditions decentralization is especially important in order to guarantee that health services are congruent with specific cultural and material realilies (Rondinelli el al. 1984). On the other hand, il has been pointed out that under these conditions local services are more likely to be prey to traditionalist and authoritarian local interests while the necessary administrative expertise may also be lacking (Rondinelli and Cheema 1983).
The health institutions and programmes in the two 
states chosen for the case study were polarized along the axes of political and administrative decentralization. Oax-aca’s social solidarity programme not only remained under central administrative command, but became even more centralized as officials grew weary of the early efforts to-wards decentralization and programme extinction. On the other hand, and in spite of the abortion of devolution the state government had its local health law passed by the legislature, enabling the governor to name a minister of health. This he did by naming the federal delegate thus gaining some power over the federal health service ma-chinery to implement his own health policy. This situation in Oaxaca resulted in mild administrative deconcentra-tion of SSA, yet a more clearly defined charter for politi-cal decentralization.
On its own part, Guerrero had a strong, centralist 
political muscle acting in favour of decentralization, a situation that favoured the establishment of a state health ministry. Decentralization even went to the municipal level and Guerrero became the only state in the country to sign agreements with most of its municipalities.
Political devolution
Devolution has been termed the type of decentralization that confers or gives back political authority to a lower governing unit (Rondinelli and Cheema 1983). Decen-tralization in Mexico was posited as this type of transfer, going beyond the deconcentration previously attempted. Devolutionary intentions did promote a new, albeit lim-ited, relationship between the state health services, state governments and ministry of health.
The state health services were created under a vari-
ety of forms, mostly pre-designed at the centre to comply with general norms and requirements. The options were ministries of health as part of the executive branch, de-partments of health dependent on a ministry of wider scope, or parastatal organizations such as institutes of health. Governors and local legislators could choose from these three options in order to adopt the organization that most suited their policies and styles of government. The state of Guerrero first adopted the model of a 
state ministry, much resembling the federal paradigm. However, with the change of governor a further decen-tralized, parastatal organism was created, the health ser-vice directorate, with its own semi-autonomous governing council. This body pretended to avoid the bureaucracy of the state machinery and to establish a more congruous relationship with the centre, given that all employees re-mained outside the state’s civil servants’ charters.    Freedom to institute changes at the state level creat-
ed problems for those in the federal ministry, as they had little control on who remained in charge, and felt that the human resources they had trained were being wasted. Fur-thermore, all administrative and technical were now open for state-level political negotiations, a situation which led in Guerrero to the coexistence of two rival teams, one in control of the governing council, the other of the director-ship of services. Such a duality and job insecurity created a great deal of disorganization, and limited the capacity of middle-level functionaries to plan and face problems with autonomy. Furthermore, these people had no ties with local-level politics and felt threatened and alienated from the federal context in which, up to then, they had moved freely. With time, this situation led to greater central con-trol, aided by influencing the appointment of a services’ director from the ranks of the federation. In Oaxaca, the duality between state and federal poli-
tics was also apparent, yet there it had a more positive balance. The naming of the federal delegate as state min-ister of health led to quite visible tensions between the demands made by the state authorities and those coming from the federation. As in Guerrero, the middle-level em-ployees were more identified with the federation and none of them had strong local political ties. They thus resented the governor’s interference in the services, a situation that was perceived as a severe distraction of the federal dele-gate from day-to-day managerial responsibilities, with too many public appearances with the governor. Furthermore, the governor channelled popular pressure to the federal services without having the corresponding federal back-ing of resources. In spite of these grievances, the power duality had some positive results, namely greater involve-ment of federal services in state politics and thus greater co-ordination with local problems.Health services decentralization in Mexico:

Financial delegation
Two constant factors set a common pattern between de-
centralized and centralized health service organizations: the continuation of separate federal and state sources of finance -without the state meddling with the federal funds; and the maintenance of the federal labour relation-ship with all ‘state’ health workers -right up to the di-rector or minister of health. Thus, all decentralized state health services, whether called ministries, departments or institutes became from the point of view of finance and control de facto, parastatal organisms of both the state and 
the federal governments. All state health services obtained direct grants or 
‘subsidies’ from both the federation and the state govern-ments. The federal grant was allotted through monthly payments and distributed by the state authorities accord-ing to a previously approved programme budget. This gave state health services a degree of autonomy over ex-penditures, yet the state government’s power was clearly limited given the centre’s influence on programming and the inaccessibility of the state treasury to the funds. Direct grants were justified by federal authorities as 
a means of avoiding both its own and the state govern-ment’s bureaucracy, and thus increasing the effectiveness of implementing national policies through local field of-fices. Decentralization was more a measure to increase central control than a democratic principle or a response to political pressure from below. Financial control by the federation thus offset the governor’s greater power to ap-point functionaries and the insertion of state health ser-vices within local politics. The state governments did not press for financial de-
volution either, as this would have implied  greater respon-sibility than they could cope with. In spite of fiscal and administrative reforms to strengthen local governments’ revenues, their share of federal fiscal appropriations was still meagre and awkward in its application, whilst their own tax bases were also weak. Assuming the financing of health through such a fiscal mechanism or through direct grants to the state treasury was tantamount to accepting de facto most of the financial burden. Control over the financing mechanism enabled the 
federal government to allocate funds through channels and organisms isolated from other statelevel legislative and executive politics. However, the federation now be-stowed on the states the legal and political responsibilities for their population’s health. Local governments -right down to the municipality -were also becoming liable to the demands from individuals, municipal authorities, oc-cupational associations and the federal government. The new responsibilities of the states’ governments 
started to change the political relationship with the cen-tre: from being passive recipients of demands for col-laboration, and evading them with equal ease, now they started to demand resources from the federation on the basis of state health plans submitted to the vote and the local legislator’s evaluation. On the other hand, richer states -such as Tabasco or Jalisco -started to pour more monies out of their own tax funds, thus shouldering the impact of the crisis. These new political responsibilities were officially channelled through the National Health Board, where the decentralized state health authorities sat with the federal minister of health to exchange points of view over finance and control. In spite of their greater political responsibilities, the 
decentralized states did not show greater local govern-ment involvement in finance than those states which remained centralized, even though all of them increased their financial burden as the economic crisis progressed. It was the still centralized states which showed greater financial decentralization, a situation congruent with our view that what occurred in the decentralized states was in fact federal financial delegation. It was noted above that the policy of decentralization was adopted giving prefer-ence to those states with greater financial autonomy, where on average the state governments contributed 17.43% of health expenditures, while those that were to remain centralized gave only 5.58”70. Yet, as the economic crisis proceeded, the centralized states doubled their share of the financial burden, whilst the decentralized states only increased theirs by 66%.
Personnel deconcentration 
All state health services employees, from the janitors to the minister or director, remained within the feder-al payroll and labour relationship. This situation came about mainly because of the unwillingness of federal au-thorities to challenge the power of the corporatist trade union structure that characterizes labour relationships with the federal government. It was felt that the work-ers’ trade union rights should not be harmed if decen-tralization were to proceed. On the other hand, no state governor was likely to accept more burdens into his or her payroll structure; and, more importantly, they could not offer the necessary incentives to deal with such a complex bureaucracy.l 313 l
The federal government provided good incentives to 
bring about the transfer of social solidarity workers onto 
the ministry’s payroll. All the latter’s salaries were levelled for this purpose to those offered by the social security in-stitute, and more workers were tenured. The offer of bet-ter working conditions and recognition of ladderranked privileges led to the transference of 93% of the 3969 so-cial solidarity workers in the integrated states. Notwith-standing these precautions, labour conflicts did arise with decentralization: key social solidarity medical personnel were offered tenure within IMSS, thus leading to sudden resource shortages and a sharp downturn of basic hospital services. The major labour conflict related to decentraliza-tion arose with the ‘horizontalization’ of the malaria verti-cal campaign that had been in existence since 1956.
Personnel decentralization was limited to deconcen-
tration of managerial authority of all labour relationships. All high-level decisions, such as the establishment of wage levels, were reserved for federal negotiation with the rep-resentatives of the still national trade union. However, the devolutionary context increased the scope and power of deconcentrated personnel decisions. The federal govern-ment ‘invited’ the state governors to be more concerned with ‘their’ workers’ problems and to consider them as part of their political constituency. In this way, high-ranking state health services’ officials received economic incentives from the state government, added to their federal salaries. Other forms of involvement were also encouraged, such as the state government’s scrutiny over the professional behaviour of the workers, and the curbing of corruption.  The federal labour statutes had always been negotiat-
ed from a centralist perspective, making them particularly unsuitable for coping with the territorial framework that a decentralized system requires to deliver services accord-ing to local needs. These problems were highlighted when the malaria health workers remained in urban areas and avoided efforts towards better territorial integration.
 
Sectoral and regional coordination
The ministry of health aimed to reinforce the participa-tion of the health sector within the COPLADES, un-der the coordination of the state minister of health or, in still-centralized states, of the federal delegate. The COP-LADES were chosen as the most efficient way of linking resources to the priorities set through the state plans, with the participation of representatives of the whole health sector and the authorities at the federal, state and munici-pal levels (Soberon 1987). One of the first concerns of ministry officials was to 
train the delegates so that they could formulate the CUD funding agreements promoted by the Ministry of Finance and Budgeting through the COPLADES. Ministry offi-cials argued that lack of training was promoting a vicious circle of underdevelopment, where only those most highly trained delegates in developed states were able to ask for and utilize federal monies channelled through the COP-LADE. Once properly trained, the delegates, or new state ministers of health, would coordinate the formulation of state health plans by the local sectoral authorities. In spite of the efforts towards decentralized sectoral 
integration, this became a difficult or even impossible task in both Guerrero and Oaxaca given the strong traditions of independent and centralized planning -much promot-ed by the vertical and autonomous implementation of the social solidarity programme during the oil boom. In the early stages of sectoral coordination in Oaxaca, conflicts arose as IMSS claimed to be covering all the non-insured population through social solidarity, thus threatening more than 200 ministry clinics with obsolescence. When talks broke down between the two institutions, the del-egated ministry’s planning officer simply wrote into the plan what he thought could be each institutions’s cov-erage. The state health plan was thus the product of the ministry in Oaxaca, complying with a blueprint supplied from the centre. By contrast, in Guerrero, the health sec-tor as a whole had greater participation in the formulation of the health plan, albeit with a visible dominance by the ministry officials. The establishment of the new, integrated and decen-
tralized health service administration in Guerrero led to an emphasis on sectoral planning and financial decentral-ization, while little attention was paid to regional coordi-nation amongst other social policy agencies. The regional ranches of the COP LADE met only sporadically and with very poor attendance. The pattern of negotiation with the population was vertical, and little breath was wasted when denying the municipal presidents’ petitions for new health centres despite their offer to shoulder construc-tion costs. On the other hand, the decentralized admin-istration made great efforts to establish decentralization agreements with most of the 70 municipal governments, sparing only around 15 of the poorest. Such agreements produced a great deal of conflict when several municipali-ties challenged the state authorities’ failure to recognize past financial agreements and felt they were being over-burdened with responsibilities. By contrast, the economi-cally important municipality of Acapulco enjoyed direct Health services decentralization in Mexico:

The impact of decentralization on equity
Decentralization was often defined by health officials and politicians as a democratizing and redistributive policy, linked to the electoral promise of striving towards a more equitable society. The consequences of decentralization for service distribution were thus expected to favour their more equitable response to health needs.

Census statistics at the municipal level were used to indicate risk factors for the prevalence of infectious diseases and infant mortality.

 The maintenance of the equitable or egalitarian pat-
tern of service distribution in Oaxaca through the eco-nomic crisis can be explained as the result of a lack of prioritization of resource assignments for key regions of the state. It seems that the politically motivated persis-tence of the dual health service infrastructure and the resistance to decentralization led to an emphasis of the status quo. The comparison between the two states shows that the incentives that were offered by the central au-thorities to decentralize were better assimilated by the richer and economically more strategic municipalities, thus turning decentralization into a distributive policy capable of stimulating further growth. Decentralization was clearly associated with important 
increases in service utilization in the urban areas. However, l 317 l
its association with the lowering of services is more prob-
lematic, given the parallel effects of the economic crisis. The lowering in health service utilization indicators among the two poorest strata was significantly greater in Guerrero than in Oaxaca (Figure 3). Here it would seem that the interinstitutional conflicts around the implementation pro-cess were responsible for the excessive drop that was greater than would have been caused by the economic crisis alone. We emphasize the negative consequences of conflicts at the central level, rather than the benefits of decentraliza-tion itself. Indeed, given the utter poverty in most of the municipalities of the lower two strata, no decentralization agreements were signed. It can be said that decentralization there had more of a ‘rebound’ effect, rather than a direct impact on planning, finance and operation. In contrast to the picture seen in the lower two strata, 
Guerrero did better for stratum 3 than Oaxaca, with only a small fall in two indicators and a similar increment in an-other two (Figure 3). This is significant because stratum 3 is where 66% of Guerrero’s population and 56% of Oaxaca’s were concentrated. The decentralization agreements signed in the mostly rural, stratum 3, municipalities of Guer-rero seem to have lent some protection to service utiliza-tion against the economic crisis, perhaps through making health services accountable at the local level. This was in spite of the conflicts observed between the state authorities and some municipalities. Given the importance of stratum 3, it can be said that decentralization as a policy structure showed a nett positive effect in the more prosperous rural areas of Guerrero, in contrast to the nett negative effect due to the implementation process in the poorest rural areas. 
Conclusions
We have analysed decentralization as a complex multi-faceted policy, determined in its benefits by the centralist, institutional and political interests affected. We have also questioned the policy’s capacity to generate and integrate services in specific development areas. Analysis at the cen-tral level revealed that, after decades of centralization and fragmentation, the policy was received with distrust by IMSS, as it threatened its hegemony over Mexican health policy. The rivalry for leadership, resources and legitima-tion at the centre -quite apart from real problems encoun-tered during implementation -undermined the expected benefits and led io an interruption of decentralization.
